questions.text: A 32-year-old professional surfer presents with complaints of reduced hearing and recurrent water trapping in the left ear. Otoscopic examination reveals as image as shown below. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical excision with canaloplasty

 

The patient is presenting with exostoses, which are benign bony growths in the external auditory canal. These are commonly seen in individuals with chronic exposure to cold water, such as surfers ("surfer’s ear"). While initially asymptomatic, they can cause conductive hearing loss, recurrent otitis externa, or water trapping.

 

  • The definitive treatment for symptomatic exostoses is surgical excision combined with canaloplasty, which removes the bony growth and widens the canal to prevent recurrence.
  • The goal is to restore patency and prevent debris/water accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical antibiotics with steroids: Useful in otitis externa, not effective for bony swellings like exostoses.

 

Option B. Ichthammol glycerine pack: Used for furuncles (boils) in the ear canal, not for exostoses.

 

Option D. Systemic antifungals: Indicated for fungal otitis externa, not bony lesions like exostoses.

 

Educational Objective:


Exostoses are benign bony outgrowths of the external auditory canal typically seen in individuals exposed to cold water. Definitive management in symptomatic cases is surgical excision with canaloplasty.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old IV drug user presents with fatigue, elevated liver enzymes, and jaundice. Further testing reveals a chronic viral hepatitis infection. Regarding hepatitis viruses and their clinical implications, which of the following statements are incorrect?

 

  1. Hepatitis A virus is associated with chronic liver disease and is commonly acquired via blood transfusion.
  2. Hepatitis E infection is particularly severe in pregnant women and may lead to fulminant liver failure.
  3. Hepatitis C is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route and carries a high risk of progression to chronic hepatitis.
  4. Hepatitis B and D can coinfect simultaneously or HDV can superinfect an HBV carrier; superinfection tends to be more severe.
  5. Hepatitis B is parenterally transmitted and causes chronic infection in a minority of patients.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

Statement 1: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, not blood transfusion, and it does not cause chronic liver disease.

 

Statement 3: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is transmitted parenterally, especially through IV drug use and transfusions (though risk from transfusion is now very low due to screening). It is not transmitted fecal-orally.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: Hepatitis E (HEV) infection can cause fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester.

 

Statement 4: Hepatitis D (HDV) requires co-infection or superinfection with HBV. Superinfection (HDV in someone already with HBV) is more severe than coinfection.

 

Statement 5: Hepatitis B (HBV) is transmitted parenterally, and chronic infection occurs in ~20% of adult cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HAV and HCV differ in transmission routes—HAV is fecal-oral and never chronic; HCV is parenteral and frequently chronic. 
  • HDV requires HBV for replication and causes more severe disease in superinfection.

choices.text: Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for follow-up after an abnormal Pap smear. Her cervical cytology reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), and colposcopy confirms cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 (CIN 2). Based on the image, which procedure is being performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

 

  • The Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LEEP) is a procedure used to remove abnormal cervical tissue, particularly in cases of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 or CIN 3). 
  • It utilizes an electrosurgical loop to excise the affected transformation zone of the cervix.
  • LEEP serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes, as the excised tissue can be sent for histopathological examination to confirm the presence and extent of dysplasia.
  • It is preferred in cases of CIN 2 or CIN 3 to prevent progression to cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical biopsy: It involves taking a small sample of tissue for diagnosis but does not remove large portions of the transformation zone.

 

Option B. Cervical conisation: It is a broader excisional procedure that removes a cone-shaped portion of the cervix, often using a scalpel or laser rather than an electrosurgical loop.

 

Option C. Cervical cerclage: It is a surgical procedure used to reinforce the cervix in cases of cervical insufficiency to prevent preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LEEP) is a common procedure used to remove abnormal cervical tissue in cases of cervical dysplasia (CIN 2 or 3).
  • It serves both as a treatment and diagnostic tool, preventing progression to invasive cervical cancer.

A 52-year-old woman presents with a severe occipital headache for 2 hours, along with photophobia and neck stiffness. 

Investigations:

  • CT Head: Normal
  • Lumbar Puncture (LP): 

 

 

  • CT Intracranial Angiogram: 

 

 

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aneurysm coiling

 

  • This patient has subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) secondary to an intracranial aneurysm rupture:
    • Thunderclap headache (sudden, severe occipital headache)
    • Signs of meningeal irritation (photophobia, neck stiffness)
    • CT head is normal, but LP confirms xanthochromia (bilirubin from RBC breakdown, confirming SAH).
    • CT angiogram identifies the aneurysm, indicating the need for aneurysm treatment.

 

Management of Aneurysmal SAH:

 

  1. Definitive Treatment:
    • Endovascular aneurysm coiling (first-line)
    • Surgical clipping (alternative in some cases)
  2. Supportive Management:
    • Nimodipine (calcium channel blocker) to prevent vasospasm (which can cause secondary ischemic stroke).
    • Blood pressure control (aiming for SBP <160 mmHg).
    • Neurosurgical referral for close monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Used for bacterial meningitis, which also causes headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness, but SAH is confirmed by xanthochromia and aneurysm on CT angiography, not infection.

 

Option C. Burr hole evacuation: Used for subdural or epidural hematomas, not SAH. SAH results from arterial aneurysm rupture, requiring coiling or clipping.

 

Option D. IV alteplase: Used for acute ischemic stroke but is contraindicated in hemorrhagic stroke (including SAH).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) requires urgent intervention with aneurysm coiling (first-line) or surgical clipping to prevent re-bleeding. Nimodipine is given to reduce the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia due to vasospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the therapeutic benefit and limitations of Sodium cromoglycate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is used to prevent exercise-induced bronchospasm but not for acute relief

 

  • Sodium cromoglycate (cromolyn sodium) is a mast cell stabilizer.
  • It inhibits degranulation of mast cells, preventing the release of histamine, leukotrienes, and other inflammatory mediators involved in bronchospasm.
  • It is not a bronchodilator and does not relieve acute asthma attacks.
  • Instead, it is used prophylactically, especially in exercise-induced asthma, where taken 15–30 minutes before exertion, it reduces the likelihood of bronchospasm.
  • It is also used in allergic conditions like allergic rhinitis and allergic conjunctivitis as a preventive agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may result in cardiac arrhythmias with prolonged use: Incorrect. Sodium cromoglycate has a very favorable safety profile. It is not known to cause cardiac arrhythmias, even with chronic inhaled use.

 

Option C. It acts by directly preventing antigen-antibody binding at the receptor level: Incorrect. Sodium cromoglycate does not interfere with antigen-antibody interactions. Instead, it inhibits downstream mast cell degranulation following IgE-mediated activation.

 

Option D. It is effective in rapidly reversing acute episodes of allergic asthma: Incorrect. Cromoglycate has no role in acute asthma management. It lacks bronchodilator action and is used only for prevention, not for symptom reversal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inhaled sodium cromoglycate is a mast cell stabilizer used prophylactically to prevent exercise-induced bronchospasm but is not effective in treating acute asthma attacks.

choices.text: Aberrant deposits of alpha-synuclein protein in the primary motor cortex
Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the basal ganglia striatum
Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra
Loss of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert

questions.text:
A 72-year-old retired professor from Kolkata is brought to the neurology clinic by his daughter due to progressive memory problems and difficulty managing daily tasks over the past year. He has started missing bill payments, repeating questions, and often gets lost in familiar surroundings. Recently, he was found wandering outside his house late at night, confused about the time and place. He struggles to recognize distant relatives and misplaces important items, believing others have stolen them. His family reports a history of similar cognitive decline in his father. He has no tremors, hallucinations, or abnormal movements.

Investigations:

  • Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE): 18/30 (suggesting moderate cognitive impairment)

What is the most likely underlying pathological change?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loss of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert

 

  • This patient’s presentation is typical of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), marked by progressive cognitive decline, memory loss, disorientation, and impaired daily functioning. 
  • The underlying pathophysiology involves the loss of cholinergic neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert, resulting in decreased acetylcholine, a key neurotransmitter for memory and learning. 
  • Additionally, beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles contribute to cerebral atrophy, particularly in the hippocampus and temporal lobes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aberrant deposits of alpha-synuclein protein in the primary motor cortex: Seen in Lewy body dementia, which includes visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and parkinsonism—none of which are seen here.

 

Option B. Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the basal ganglia striatum: Characteristic of Huntington’s disease, which causes chorea and psychiatric symptoms, not progressive amnesia.

 

Option C. Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra: Seen in Parkinson’s disease, presenting with motor symptoms (tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity), not early cognitive decline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and involves degeneration of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert, leading to acetylcholine deficiency. 
  • Hallmark pathological findings include amyloid plaques and tau protein tangles.
  • Management includes cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and memantine for symptomatic relief.

choices.text: Scrotal exploration on the affected side

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe right-sided scrotal pain and nausea for the past 4 hours. On examination, the scrotum is swollen, erythematous, and extremely tender. The pain worsens when the testis is elevated (negative Prehn’s sign). Doppler ultrasound confirms decreased blood flow to the affected testis. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral scrotal exploration

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of testicular torsion. It warrants immediate ipsilateral scrotal exploration.
  • However, due to the likelihood of a contra-lateral anatomical defect, simultaneous contralateral exploration is also mandated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scrotal exploration on the affected side: Unilateral scrotal exploration will address only the currently twisted testis.

 

Option C. Inguinal exploration on affected side and D. Bilateral inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration is done when testicular malignancy is suspected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Testicular torsion warrants immediate ipsilateral as well as contralateral exploration.

Call an ambulance and admit to the hospital

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman from Jaipur presents to the primary care clinic with generalized abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and persistent vomiting for the past 24 hours. She denies any recent travel, consumption of outside food, or contact with others who are ill. On examination, she appears lethargic, has diffuse abdominal tenderness, hyperactive bowel sounds, but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Her vitals are stable, and there are no signs of severe dehydration. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bed rest and oral rehydration solution

 

  • This patient's symptoms of generalized abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and vomiting for 24 hours, along with diffuse abdominal tenderness and hyperactive bowel sounds, suggest gastroenteritis, most likely viral in nature. 
  • Since the patient does not exhibit signs of systemic upset, severe dehydration, or a more serious underlying condition, the management of choice is bed rest and oral rehydration solution (ORS) to prevent dehydration and support recovery. 
  • Gastroenteritis typically resolves on its own, and oral rehydration is sufficient in most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Call an ambulance and admit to the hospital: Admission to the hospital is generally not required unless the patient shows signs of severe dehydration, shock, or significant systemic infection. There is no evidence here to suggest the need for hospital admission.

 

Option C. IV fluids + IV antibiotics: IV fluids and antibiotics are typically reserved for patients with severe dehydration, systemic infection, or bacterial causes of gastroenteritis, which is not suggested by this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. Oral antibiotics: Antibiotics are generally not needed for viral gastroenteritis and should not be prescribed unless there is clear evidence of a bacterial infection, which is not supported by the patient's history or examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Gastroenteritis is commonly viral, and most cases are self-limiting. The primary treatment involves oral rehydration solution (ORS) to maintain hydration and support recovery. 
  • Antibiotics and IV fluids are not typically required unless there are signs of severe illness or dehydration.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are True/False regarding a patient with Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)?

 

  1. Myoclonic jerks are usually seen.
  2. EEG shows periodic complexes with stereotyped delta waves.
  3. SSPE is due to past varicella infection occurring years before symptom onset.
  4. Diagnosis is established by serum electrophoresis.
  5. Seizures may occur during the disease course.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-T, 2-T, 3-F, 4-F, 5-T

 

Statement 1 – True: SSPE is a classic cause of myoclonic jerks in children.

 

Statement 2 – True: EEG typically shows periodic high-voltage stereotyped delta wave bursts every 4–10 seconds.

 

Statement 3 – False: SSPE is a late complication of measles virus infection, not varicella.

 

Statement 4 – False: Serum and CSF anti-measles antibodies, not electrophoresis, confirm the diagnosis.

 

Statement 5 – True: Seizures can develop during the disease course.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • SSPE is a progressive, fatal complication of measles infection characterized by myoclonic jerks, periodic EEG complexes, and cognitive decline. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by anti-measles antibody detection in serum and CSF.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of renal transplantation presents with malaise, fever, and rising serum creatinine. A renal biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltration and signs of acute cellular rejection. Immunohistochemistry reveals abundant expression of MHC class I molecules on the tubular epithelial cells, and CD8+ T lymphocytes are identified infiltrating the renal parenchyma. Which of the following best describes the type of antigen presented and the responding T-cell subset involved in this rejection process?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endogenous antigen; CD8+ T cells

 

  • MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, such as viral or cytosolic proteins synthesized within infected host cells.
  • These antigens are processed by the proteasome, transported to the endoplasmic reticulum, and loaded onto MHC I molecules.
  • MHC I presents antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, which can directly kill infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exogenous antigen; CD8+ T cells: Incorrect. CD8+ T cells respond to endogenous, not exogenous, antigens.

 

Option B. Endogenous antigen; CD4+ T cells: Incorrect. CD4+ T cells respond to exogenous antigens presented via MHC II.

 

Option D. Exogenous antigen; CD19+ B cells: Incorrect. CD19 is a B cell marker, not involved in MHC I/II presentation pathways directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MHC class I presents endogenous antigens (e.g., viral proteins) to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens to CD4+ helper T cells.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man has had bone pain, worse in the spine and ribs, for 3 months. His mother passed away from lung cancer at the age of 67. He has mild pallor and multiple bruises all over his body.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL 
  • Serum calcium: 11.36 mg/dL
  • Blood film: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

 

  • The patient's bone pain, particularly in the spine and ribs, combined with family history of malignancy, mild pallor, bruising, anaemia, and hypercalcaemia, and the stacking of red blood cells (rouleaux formation) on the blood film, strongly suggest multiple myeloma. Here's why:
    • Multiple myeloma is a hematologic malignancy characterized by abnormal proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow. It often presents with the CRAB features:
      • C: Hypercalcaemia (elevated serum calcium levels due to osteoclast activation and bone resorption)
      • R: Renal failure (due to deposition of light chains in the kidneys)
      • A: Anaemia (due to bone marrow suppression)
      • B: Bone pain (caused by osteolytic lesions, commonly affecting the spine and ribs)
      • I: Infection (due to impaired immune function)
      • The stacking of red blood cells (rouleaux formation) seen on the blood film is characteristic of multiple myeloma and is due to the increased protein in the blood (particularly immunoglobulins) from the malignant plasma cells.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bone metastasis: Bone metastasis would typically cause bone pain, but it would not explain the hypercalcaemia, anaemia, or rouleaux formation seen in the blood film. Also, bruising is not commonly seen in metastatic disease, whereas multiple myeloma can cause bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and bone marrow involvement.

 

Option B. Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML): CML typically presents with leukocytosis, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia, rather than bone pain, hypercalcaemia, and rouleaux formation. The blood film in CML would show immature white blood cells, not rouleaux.

 

Option C. Hodgkin lymphoma: While Hodgkin lymphoma can present with pallor, bruising, and lymphadenopathy, it would not explain the hypercalcaemia, bone pain, or rouleaux formation. Additionally, Hodgkin lymphoma would typically show Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy, not findings of abnormal plasma cells as seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder that presents with the CRAB symptoms (calcium, renal, anaemia, bleeding, bones, infection), and it often causes bone pain (especially in the spine and ribs), hypercalcaemia, anaemia, and renal impairment.
  • Rouleaux formation on the blood film is a classic finding in multiple myeloma, due to increased immunoglobulins in the blood.
  • The treatment of multiple myeloma involves chemotherapy, stem cell transplantation, and bisphosphonates to manage bone pain and hypercalcaemia.

choices.text: Resmetirom is utilized for the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, functioning as an insulin sensitizer by activating PPAR-gamma receptors to improve glucose utilization.
Resmetirom is used in the management of atrial fibrillation, where it acts as a potassium channel blocker to slow down heart rate and improve heart rhythm.
Resmetirom is indicated for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), acting as a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist to reduce liver fat and fibrosis.
Resmetirom is prescribed for the lowering of high cholesterol, operating as an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor to reduce the production of cholesterol in the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action and clinical application of Resmetirom?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resmetirom is indicated for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), acting as a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist to reduce liver fat and fibrosis.

 

  • Resmetirom (MGL-3196) is a selective THR-β agonist developed for the treatment of NASH, a chronic liver disease associated with fat accumulation, inflammation, and fibrosis.
  • THR-β receptors are highly expressed in the liver, and selective activation improves hepatic lipid metabolism, reduces liver fat, and may reverse fibrosis.
  • Resmetirom targets the underlying pathophysiology of NASH without causing the systemic (especially cardiac) side effects seen with non-selective thyroid hormone therapies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPAR-gamma activation: Describes thiazolidinediones, like pioglitazone, used in Type 2 DM, not NASH-specific and not the MOA of Resmetirom.

 

Option B. Potassium channel blockade: Describes antiarrhythmic class III drugs (e.g., amiodarone), not applicable to Resmetirom, which has no direct cardiac electrophysiologic effects.

 

Option D. HMG-CoA reductase inhibition: Describes statins, which lower cholesterol but do not directly treat NASH. Resmetirom can lower LDL, but its primary action is via THR-β, not HMG-CoA inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resmetirom is a selective thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist used in the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), where it reduces hepatic fat and fibrosis by improving liver-specific lipid metabolism.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with sleepwalking episodes, where he is found roaming in the house with a blank stare. He is confused upon awakening and recalls nothing about the event. Which sleep stage is most associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 3 NREM

 

  • The patient’s presentation is consistent with sleepwalking (somnambulism), which involves ambulation during sleep with a blank stare, unresponsiveness, confusion upon awakening, and no memory of the event. 
  • These features are classic for parasomnias arising from deep non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep, specifically Stage 3 NREM (also called slow-wave sleep). 
  • Sleepwalking typically occurs during the first third of the night, when Stage 3 NREM sleep predominates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. REM sleep: REM sleep is associated with vivid dreaming and atonia, not sleepwalking. REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) involves acting out dreams but is more common in older adults and neurologic conditions like Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B. Stage 1 NREM: Stage 1 is a light transitional sleep stage and not associated with parasomnias like sleepwalking.

 

Option C. Stage 2 NREM: Though Stage 2 comprises the largest portion of sleep, sleepwalking arises from deeper slow-wave stages, not Stage 2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Somnambulism (sleepwalking), the individual gets up from the bed and aimlessly wanders without getting fully awake. 
  • More complex activities like dressing, moving around, or driving, maybe there. 
  • No attempt should be made to wake up the sleepwalker, as he may get confused and attack. It typically occurs during stage 3 of NREM sleep.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with posterior knee pain after a motorcycle crash. MRI of the knee is obtained, and the marked structure is suspected to be the source of injury. Based on the clinical presentation and the anatomical location of the marked structure, which of the following is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior cruciate ligament

 

  • The Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) originates from the posterior intercondylar tibia and inserts on the medial femoral condyle. 
  • It plays a critical role in preventing posterior translation of the tibia, particularly when the knee is flexed. 
  • In the context of a direct blow to the flexed knee, such as a motorcycle crash, the PCL is the most likely structure to be injured.
  • MRI in such settings typically shows a thick band-like structure, and if that marked structure runs from posterior tibia toward the femur, it corresponds with the anatomical location and orientation of the PCL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral meniscus: A wedge-shaped cartilage structure located between the lateral femoral condyle and tibia. It is not a ligament and does not match the location or injury mechanism.

 

Option B. Anterior cruciate ligament: Runs from the anterior tibia to the lateral femoral condyle, anterior to the PCL. Commonly injured with twisting or hyperextension, not with posterior force to a flexed knee.

 

Option D. Medial meniscus: Cartilage structure between the medial femoral condyle and tibia; not implicated in the described trauma or consistent with the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The posterior cruciate ligament is commonly injured in trauma to a flexed knee, such as dashboard or motorcycle injuries. 
  • On MRI, it appears as a band from the posterior tibia to the medial femoral condyle, and damage here leads to posterior knee instability.

choices.text: Accumulation of abnormally folded, β-pleated prion proteins that induce conformational change in normal proteins
Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family due to rapidly progressive dementia over several weeks. He has developed myoclonus and difficulty with coordination. MRI shows hyperintensities in the caudate and putamen. EEG reveals periodic sharp wave complexes. Brain biopsy shows multiple small vacuoles in neurons and glial cells, giving the tissue a “spongy” appearance. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Accumulation of abnormally folded, β-pleated prion proteins that induce conformational change in normal proteins

 

  • This patient presents with features highly suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a form of spongiform encephalopathy:
    • Rapidly progressive dementia
    • Myoclonus
    • EEG changes (periodic sharp waves)
    • Spongiform change on histology (intracellular vacuoles in neurons and glial cells)

 

 

  • Spongiform encephalopathies are caused by abnormal prion proteins, which are β-pleated in structure and can convert the normal α-helical form into the pathologic form. 
  • This leads to accumulation, neuronal damage, and a self-propagating cycle of protein misfolding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoantibody-mediated demyelination of central white matter: Describes multiple sclerosis, not prion disease.

 

Option B. Beta-amyloid accumulation in cortical neurons: Seen in Alzheimer disease, which is slowly progressive, not rapidly progressing with myoclonus or spongiform changes.

 

Option D. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau: Also associated with Alzheimer disease, not the prion-mediated mechanism seen in spongiform encephalopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spongiform encephalopathy is caused by accumulation of β-pleated prion proteins which convert normal α-helical prion proteins into the abnormal form, leading to vacuolar degeneration of brain tissue.

questions.text: The celery stalk is a classic sign of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucoid degeneration of ACL

 

  • Mucoid degeneration of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) involves the accumulation of mucinous material within the ligament. 
  • On MRI, this appears as a thickened ACL with increased signal intensity, often described as a "celery stalk" appearance due to the linear, striated pattern. 
  • This condition can weaken the ligament, and cause pain, and instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hoffa fat pad inflammation: The Hoffa fat pad is a triangular pad of fat located behind and beneath the patellar tendon. Inflammation of this fat pad (Hoffa's syndrome) causes pain in the front of the knee, especially with extension. Clinical findings include tenderness and swelling at the inferolateral and inferomedial borders of the patellar tendon.

 

 

Option C. Meniscal degeneration: Meniscal degeneration refers to the breakdown of the meniscal cartilage. It can cause pain, clicking, and locking of the knee. MRI findings include increased signal within the meniscus.

 

 

Option D. Cartilage degeneration: Cartilage degeneration (osteoarthritis) involves the progressive loss of articular cartilage. It causes pain, stiffness, and swelling of the knee. MRI findings include joint space narrowing, subchondral bone changes, and osteophytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "celery stalk" sign is a specific MRI finding that is highly characteristic of mucoid degeneration of the ACL.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic gallstones. On post-operative day 3, she develops fever, right upper quadrant pain, and signs of sepsis. Laboratory investigations reveal leukocytosis and deranged liver function tests. Imaging shows a bile leak and a right subhepatic fluid collection. ERCP suggests bile duct transection involving the aberrant right hepatic duct. Based on Strasberg's classification, what is the most likely type of injury and the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C, subhepatic drain

 

  • Type C injury refers to transection without ligation of an aberrant right hepatic duct, a scenario commonly encountered in laparoscopic cholecystectomy when aberrant ducts draining into the cystic duct are injured and not ligated, leading to a persistent bile leak.
  • The patient in this case developed features of a bile leak and sepsis, confirmed by imaging and ERCP, making Type C injury the most appropriate classification.
  • The next step would be to place a subhepatic drain to clear the collection and control sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type B, biliary stenting and Option B. Type B, Subhepatic drain: Refers to occlusion (not transection) of the biliary tree, particularly aberrant right hepatic ducts.

 

Option D. Type C, hepaticojejunostomy: Reconstruction is done at a later stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strasberg classification categorizes bile duct injuries during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 
  • Type C injury is defined as transection without ligation of an aberrant right hepatic duct, commonly resulting in postoperative bile leaks requiring drainage and definitive biliary repair.

 

Strasberg Classification: 

 

Type A - Injury to the cystic duct or from minor hepatic ducts draining the liver bed. 

 

Type B - Occlusion of biliary tree, commonly aberrant right hepatic duct(s) 

 

Type C - Transection without ligation of aberrant right hepatic duct(s) 

 

Type D - Lateral injury to a major bile duct. 

 

Type E (1-5) - Injury to the main hepatic duct; classified according to level of injury (i.e., below). E1 (Bismuth type 1) - Injury more than 2 cm from confluence 

 

E2 (Bismuth type 2) - Injury less than 2 cm from confluence 

 

E3 (Bismuth type 3) - Injury at the confluence; confluence intact 

 

E4 (Bismuth type 4) - Destruction of the biliary confluence 

 

E5 (Bismuth type 5) - Injury to aberrant right hepatic duct

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with dysuria and urethral discharge. A urethral smear is taken and cultured. The image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycoplasma genitalium

 

  • The “fried egg” appearance of colonies on culture is classically associated with Mycoplasma species, especially Mycoplasma hominis or Mycoplasma genitalium, which are known causes of nongonococcal urethritis.
    • Mycoplasma lacks a cell wall, which makes it resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics and also gives rise to the distinctive colony appearance.
    • It requires special cholesterol-enriched media to grow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: An obligate intracellular organism, does not grow on standard culture media; identified by NAATs or cell culture.

 

Option C. Mobiluncus spp: Associated with bacterial vaginosis, not typically involved in male urethritis and does not show fried egg colonies.

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycoplasma species produce fried egg–shaped colonies on special media and are important causes of nongonococcal urethritis. 
  • They lack a cell wall and require cholesterol-containing media for growth.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with complaints of loss of interest, fatigue, insomnia, and recurrent feelings of worthlessness. She also reports hearing a voice telling her she is a burden on her family. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psychotic depression

 

  • The patient presents with core symptoms of major depressive disorder—anhedonia (loss of interest), fatigue, insomnia, and worthlessness—along with auditory hallucinations (a voice telling her she is a burden). 
  • When psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions or hallucinations) occur exclusively during depressive episodes, the diagnosis is major depressive disorder with psychotic features, also called psychotic depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melancholic depression: A subtype of depression marked by loss of pleasure in all activities, diurnal variation (worse in the morning), and psychomotor changes, but does not include psychotic features.

 

Option B. Persistent depressive disorder (Dysthymia): Involves chronic low mood for at least 2 years, but without psychotic symptoms. The episode here appears severe.

 

Option D. Schizoaffective disorder: Diagnosed when psychotic symptoms occur independently of mood symptoms for at least 2 weeks. In this case, the psychotic symptoms are only present during the depressive episode, ruling out schizoaffective disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of depressive symptoms with delusions/hallucinations. 
  • Psychotic symptoms can be mood congruent/mood incongruent. If the content of delusions/hallucinations matches the mood, it's called mood congruent; if it doesn't match, it's called mood incongruent. 
  • For example, a patient with severe depression develops a delusion that the world is ending. It is an example of mood-congruent delusion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of stable exertional angina presents with chest discomfort brought on by physical activity, which is relieved with rest. His ECG and cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. He is started on an anti-anginal drug that works via a dual mechanism—by releasing nitric oxide (NO) and activating ATP-sensitive potassium (K⁺) channels, leading to vasodilation and cardioprotective effects. Which of the following medications acts via this dual mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nicorandil

 

  • Nicorandil has a dual mechanism:
    1. It acts as a nitrate donor, releasing nitric oxide (NO), which activates guanylate cyclase, increasing cGMP, and leading to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
    2. It opens ATP-sensitive K⁺ channels, causing hyperpolarization of vascular smooth muscle and further vasodilation.
  • These effects improve coronary blood flow, reduce preload and afterload, and provide cardioprotection, making it useful in stable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ivabradine: Selectively inhibits the If (funny) current in the sinoatrial node, lowering heart rate without affecting contractility or vasodilation. It does not release NO or activate K⁺ channels.

 

Option C. Trimetazidine: A metabolic modulator that improves myocardial efficiency by shifting energy substrate use from fatty acid to glucose oxidation. It has no vasodilatory or NO-mediated effects.

 

Option D. Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN): A nitrate that works via NO release, causing vasodilation, but it does not activate potassium channels. Thus, it does not have a dual mechanism like nicorandil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nicorandil is an anti-anginal drug that works via a dual mechanism: it donates nitric oxide for vasodilation and opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels, providing both hemodynamic and cardioprotective effects.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man working as a cook in a residential hostel is undergoing screening after it was found that he had been diagnosed with enteric fever (typhoid) two years ago. He remains asymptomatic but is being evaluated for a possible chronic carrier state of Salmonella typhi. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm chronic carrier status in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vi agglutination test

 

  • In a patient with a history of enteric fever, especially someone in the food-handling profession, it is essential to rule out chronic carriage of Salmonella typhi. 
  • Chronic carriers may shed the bacteria intermittently in stool or urine, often due to colonization of the gallbladder.
  • The Vi agglutination test detects antibodies against the Vi capsular antigen of S. typhi, which are typically elevated in chronic carriers.
  • It is used as a screening tool for identifying individuals at risk of transmitting the infection long after clinical resolution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood culture in brain heart infusion broth: Useful in acute cases, but in chronic carriers, bacteraemia is uncommon, making this test less useful.

 

Option C. Widal test: Detects antibodies against S. typhi antigens (O and H), but it is not reliable for diagnosing carrier state and can remain falsely positive for months after infection.

 

Option D. Stool culture on selective media: May detect S. typhi in carriers, but intermittent shedding can lead to false negatives; not as reliable or specific as the Vi agglutination test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Vi agglutination test is the preferred method to screen for chronic carriers of Salmonella typhi, especially in asymptomatic individuals with a history of enteric fever.

questions.text: A body is recovered from a freshwater canal. During autopsy, the lungs appear ballooned, waterlogged, and show soft, pale-pinkish patches over their surface, each measuring about 1–2 cm in diameter. These lesions are believed to result from rupture of alveolar walls due to increased intrathoracic pressure during forceful inhalation of water. Which of the following findings is most likely being described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paltauf’s hemorrhages

 

The question describes classic autopsy findings in a case of freshwater drowning, particularly the presence of pinkish patches on the external surface of the lungs, which measure 1–2 cm. These are known as Paltauf’s hemorrhages, caused by rupture of alveolar walls due to excessive pressure during forceful inspiration of water. Though not pathognomonic, their presence supports a diagnosis of ante-mortem drowning when correlated with other findings such as emphysema aquosum, frothy fluid in airways, and overdistended lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Battle’s sign: Refers to bruising over the mastoid region, indicating basilar skull fracture, and is not related to pulmonary or drowning findings.

 

Option C. Petechial hemorrhages: These are pinpoint capillary bleeds, usually seen in asphyxial deaths, particularly in the eyes, face, and serous surfaces. They are much smaller and do not resemble the described lung lesions.

 

Option D. Tardieu’s spots: These are larger petechiae due to rupture of capillaries under high pressure in asphyxia. Although seen in suffocation, they are not pale-pinkish pleural patches as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paltauf’s hemorrhages are soft, pink, patchy hemorrhages on the lung surface seen in drowning, resulting from alveolar wall rupture during forced inhalation of water.

questions.text: A hospital administrator is implementing a staff motivation and goal-setting strategy based on behavioral science principles to improve team performance and individual accountability. Which of the following techniques best aligns with this approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Management by Objective

 

  • Management by Objective (MBO) is a technique rooted in behavioral sciences, particularly organizational behavior and motivation theory. 
  • It involves setting clear, measurable goals that are agreed upon by both managers and employees. 
  • The method focuses on improving performance, encouraging employee involvement, and aligning personal goals with organizational objectives.
  • MBO uses feedback, communication, and behavioral motivation—all grounded in behavioral science—to enhance accountability and productivity in healthcare teams and systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strategic decision modeling: This refers to logical frameworks or algorithms used in decision-making, often based on operations research, not behavior sciences.

 

Option C. Systems process mapping: Related to systems analysis, which examines workflows, inputs, and outputs in a system. It is technical/systemic, not behavioral in nature.

 

Option D. Healthcare network analysis: This is used to study relationships between entities (e.g., referral patterns, disease transmission). It is data-structural, not based on behavioral sciences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management by Objective is a behavioral science-based technique that uses goal-setting and feedback to improve individual and organizational performance.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primi woman in active labor is examined at 8:30 AM, and her cervix is found to be 5 cm dilated. Given the normal rate of cervical dilation in primi women, at what time is she expected to reach full cervical dilation if labor progresses normally?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1:30 PM

 

  • In multiparous women, the expected rate of cervical dilation in active labor is 1 cm per hour.
  • This patient is 5 cm dilated at 8:30 AM, and full dilation is 10 cm.
  • She needs to dilate 5 more cm to reach full dilation.
  • Since the rate of dilation is 1 cm per hour, she is expected to fully dilate in 5 hours.
  • 8:30 AM + 5 hours = 1:30 PM, which is the expected time for full cervical dilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In multiparous women, the cervix dilates at approximately 1 cm per hour during active labor. If a patient is 5 cm dilated at 8:30 AM, she is expected to be fully dilated (10 cm) by 1:30 PM if labor progresses normally.

questions.text: A public health student is studying international collaborations that supported post-independence development in India. One of the major initiatives was the Colombo Plan, which involved contributions from various countries in sectors like health, education, and industry. Which of the following statements correctly reflects the contributions under this plan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canada contributed Cobalt-60 radiation units to Indian healthcare institutions

 

  • The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was a regional initiative aimed at strengthening economic and social development in Asia-Pacific countries.
  • It involved contributions from developed nations, including Canada, Australia, and the UK, to support newly independent countries like India.
  • One notable health sector contribution under the plan was from Canada, which supplied Cobalt-60 teletherapy units used for cancer treatment in Indian medical institutions—marking a significant boost to India's early radiotherapy infrastructure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The plan focused exclusively on industrial development, without addressing agriculture: Incorrect. The Colombo Plan included both industrial and agricultural development, along with health, education, and technical cooperation.

 

Option B. AIIMS New Delhi was built with assistance from the United Kingdom under the plan: Incorrect. AIIMS, New Delhi was established with assistance from the New Zealand under The Colombo Plan

 

Option D. The Colombo Plan offered no contribution toward medical education or health systems: Incorrect. The plan contributed significantly to healthcare and education, including equipment, training, and institutional support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supported Indian healthcare by donating Cobalt-60 therapy units, contributing to early radiotherapy services in the country.
