questions.text: A national TB control program is trying to track the underlying transmission trend of tuberculosis (TB) in a population, independent of the effects of ongoing treatment and case detection strategies. Which of the following is the best indicator for assessing the long-term trend of TB unaffected by current control measures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual risk of infection

 

  • The Annual Risk of Infection (ARI) refers to the probability of an individual acquiring TB infection in one year. 
  • It is a direct indicator of the community transmission level of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is not affected by treatment interventions or case detection rates, making it a robust indicator for monitoring TB trends over time.
  • ARI reflects ongoing transmission and helps identify whether latent infection rates are increasing, even if diagnosed or treated TB cases fluctuate due to programmatic improvements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Percentage of latent TB in adults: Latent TB infection is common in endemic countries and reflects cumulative past exposure, not the current trend or annual transmission.

 

Option C. Percentage of multidrug-resistant TB: MDR-TB reflects treatment failure, poor compliance, or improper drug use. It is influenced by control measures, not a pure transmission indicator.

 

Option D. Prevalence of active pulmonary TB: This is affected by treatment coverage, diagnosis rates, and public health interventions, and thus does not reflect underlying transmission alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Annual Risk of Infection (ARI) is the best indicator of tuberculosis transmission trends, as it remains unaffected by control efforts and reflects true infection risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman repeatedly seeks reassurance that her skin blemishes make her look ugly, although no abnormality is visible. She has visited multiple dermatologists without relief. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cognitive behavioral therapy

 

  • The patient presents with preoccupation with an imagined or minor defect in appearance and repeated reassurance-seeking, despite no visible abnormality. 
  • This clinical picture is characteristic of Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), a somatic-type obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorder. 
  • The first-line treatment is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), especially with components like exposure and response prevention and cognitive restructuring. 
  • CBT helps patients challenge distorted beliefs about appearance and reduce compulsive behaviors such as mirror-checking or seeking reassurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electroconvulsive therapy: ECT is used for severe depression, catatonia, or treatment-resistant psychosis, but it is not indicated for BDD.
 

Option C. Low-dose antipsychotics: Antipsychotics are not first-line for BDD. They may be used adjunctively in cases of delusional intensity, but CBT remains the primary treatment.
 

Option D. Reassurance and dermatological procedures: Reassurance and cosmetic procedures often worsen BDD symptoms, as they reinforce the maladaptive preoccupation. Patients rarely benefit and continue to seek interventions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is characterized by the preoccupation with an imagined defect in body appearance.
  • In case, a slight physical anomaly is present, the patient's concern for the same is exaggerated.
  • The location of the imagined defect is usually hair, nose and skin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is being evaluated as part of a clinical trial testing the effects of a new chemotherapeutic drug targeting proliferating cells. To determine whether the treatment is affecting the rate of DNA synthesis, a sample is taken from the patient’s rapidly dividing bone marrow cells. Which of the following radioactive compounds would provide the most accurate measurement of ongoing DNA replication in these cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymidine

 

The most accurate way to measure DNA synthesis is by tracking the incorporation of radioactively labeled thymidine into newly synthesized DNA strands. Thymidine is a deoxyribonucleoside used exclusively in DNA (not RNA). During the S phase of the cell cycle, cells incorporate radiolabeled thymidine (e.g., tritiated thymidine) into DNA. This specificity makes thymidine the ideal marker for assessing DNA replication rates in proliferating cells, such as bone marrow or tumor cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guanine: Guanine is a purine base found in both DNA and RNA. Measuring its incorporation would not distinguish between DNA and RNA synthesis, making it less accurate for specifically tracking DNA replication.

 

Option C. Phosphate: Radioactive phosphate (³²P) can be incorporated into many biomolecules, including DNA, RNA, ATP, and phospholipids. Because of its non-specificity, it is not suitable for accurately measuring only DNA synthesis.

 

Option D. Adenine: Like guanine, adenine is found in both DNA and RNA, so radioactive adenine would be incorporated into both nucleic acids, which limits its specificity for detecting DNA synthesis alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioactive thymidine is used to accurately measure DNA synthesis, as it is incorporated only into DNA, not RNA, during cell replication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with localized pain and swelling in the forearm region of the hand. Radiographs show a lytic lesion extending to the subchondral bone. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumour

 

  • GCTs are benign but locally aggressive tumors that typically occur in the epiphysis of long bones, often extending to the subchondral bone.
  • They present as lytic lesions on x-ray, sometimes with a "soap bubble" appearance, but often just a lytic look.
  • The patient's age and the location of the lesion in the hip (likely involving the proximal femur, a common GCT site) strongly suggest GCT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Simple Bone Cyst (SBC): SBCs are fluid-filled benign bone lesions that are more common in children and adolescents. Radiographically, they typically appear as well-defined, centrally located lytic lesions with a thin cortex. Simple bone cysts are more common in the proximal humerus and proximal femur of children. While they can occur in the hip, the typical age and radiographic appearance are less consistent with SBC.

 

 

Option C. Adamantinoma: Adamantinoma is a rare, low-grade malignant bone tumor that typically occurs in the tibia. Radiographically, it often presents as a multilocular lytic lesion. It's extremely rare in the femur or hip.

 

 

Option D. Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that is more common in children and adolescents. Radiographically, it typically shows aggressive bone destruction with periosteal reaction (e.g., onion skinning, Codman triangle). Ewing's sarcoma is also less common in the proximal femur, when compared to GCT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant Cell Tumor: Lytic lesion in the epiphysis, extending to subchondral bone, in a patient aged 20-40.
  • Simple Bone Cyst: Well-defined, central lytic lesion, more common in children.
  • Adamantinoma: Multilocular lytic lesion, typically in the tibia.
  • Ewing's Sarcoma: Aggressive bone destruction with periosteal reaction, more common in children.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Leiomyomas are incorrect? 

 

  1. The tumor arises from endometrial glandular tissue under the influence of progesterone.
  2. Leiomyomas are estrogen-sensitive and commonly enlarge during pregnancy.
  3. Postmenopausal regression of these tumors is frequently observed due to hormonal decline.
  4. These tumors are usually solitary and highly vascular.
  5. Although often asymptomatic, patients may present with abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, or a palpable pelvic mass.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Statement 1: Incorrect — Leiomyomas originate from smooth muscle cells of the myometrium, not endometrial glandular tissue. While both estrogen and progesterone can influence growth, estrogen is the primary driver.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect — Leiomyomas are commonly multiple, not solitary. They are also typically poorly vascularized, which makes them prone to degeneration (e.g., red degeneration in pregnancy), not "highly vascular."

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: Correct — Leiomyomas are estrogen-dependent tumors and often enlarge during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels.

 

Statement 3: Correct — They typically shrink after menopause when estrogen levels fall, reflecting hormone dependency.

 

Statement 5: Correct — Most leiomyomas are asymptomatic, but may cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pressure, infertility, or present as a palpable mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors of the myometrium that are estrogen-dependent, often multiple, and may present with bleeding, infertility, or pelvic pressure. 
  • They regress after menopause.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman from Indore presents with progressive abdominal discomfort, early satiety, bloating, and decreased urine output for the past month. She also reports episodes of visible blood in the urine and a dull aching pain in both flanks. Her medical history is notable for hypertension, and her younger brother is on dialysis for chronic kidney disease. On examination, her blood pressure is 154/93 mmHg, and she has mild abdominal tenderness with ballotable bilateral flank masses. What is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal Ultrasound (US)

 

  • This patient has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), suggested by:
  • Family history of PKD
  • Hypertension (common early finding in PKD)
  • Flank pain and hematuria (due to cyst rupture or hemorrhage)
  • Palpable kidneys (enlarged due to multiple renal cysts)

 

Why Renal Ultrasound (US)?

 

  • First-line test for diagnosing ADPKD
  • High sensitivity and specificity
  • Diagnostic criteria for ADPKD on ultrasound:
    • <30 years: ≥2 cysts (unilateral or bilateral)
    • 30–59 years: ≥2 cysts in each kidney
    • ≥60 years: ≥4 cysts in each kidney

 

Ultrasound is preferred over genetic testing, as it is cheaper, noninvasive, and widely available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genetic Testing:

 

  • PKD1 and PKD2 gene mutations confirm ADPKD, but genetic testing is not necessary for diagnosis in most cases.
  • Renal ultrasound is faster and cost-effective.
  • Genetic testing is usually reserved for inconclusive cases or early detection in family planning.

 

Option C. Serum Creatinine:

 

  • Serum creatinine helps assess kidney function, but it does not diagnose PKD.
  • Patients with early PKD may have normal renal function despite cystic changes.

 

Option D. Urinalysis:

 

  • May show hematuria or mild proteinuria, but it is not diagnostic for PKD.
  • Useful for ruling out concurrent infection but not the first-line investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal ultrasound is the first-line investigation for diagnosing autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). It is noninvasive, widely available, and can confirm the presence of multiple cysts. Genetic testing is usually reserved for inconclusive cases.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Urticaria Pigmentosa and Darier’s disease are true? 

 

  1. Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common form of cutaneous mastocytosis and is due to mast cell accumulation in the skin.
  2. Darier’s sign, seen in urticaria pigmentosa, is elicited by firm stroking that leads to increased induration or piloerection.
  3. Darier’s disease presents with greasy, dirty-appearing papules on the trunk and flexures, and nail changes like red and white longitudinal streaks.
  4. A point mutation in the c-KIT proto-oncogene plays a role in the pathogenesis of urticaria pigmentosa.
  5. Pseudo-Darier sign is classically seen in urticaria pigmentosa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1: True – Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common variant of cutaneous mastocytosis and is due to dermal mast cell accumulation.

 

Statement 3: True – Darier’s disease presents with keratotic papules on seborrheic areas and flexures, with characteristic nail findings including longitudinal red/white lines and distal notching.

 

Statement 4: True – The c-KIT mutation is implicated in urticaria pigmentosa.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2: False – This describes the Pseudo-Darier sign, which is seen in smooth muscle hamartoma. True Darier’s sign is urtication and erythema after rubbing the lesion, seen in urticaria pigmentosa.

 

Statement 5: False – Pseudo-Darier sign is seen in smooth muscle hamartoma, not in urticaria pigmentosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urticaria pigmentosa is a mast cell disorder presenting with brown macules that urticate upon stroking (Darier’s sign). It is associated with c-KIT mutations. 
  • Darier’s disease, on the other hand, is a keratinization disorder with flexural papules, nail changes, and oral mucosal lesions, and should not be confused with Darier’s sign.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents for a routine checkup. She has a sedentary lifestyle and a BMI of 26. She has a history of smoking one pack per day but recently quit. At her last visit, she was advised to take calcium and vitamin D supplements but has not been compliant. A DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.5, indicating osteoporosis. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bisphosphonates

 

  • This patient has osteoporosis, as evidenced by a T-score of -2.5 on DEXA scan. Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score ≤ -2.5 and is associated with an increased risk of fragility fractures.
  • Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate, risedronate, zoledronic acid) are the first-line treatment for osteoporosis.
  • These drugs work by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, increasing bone mineral density (BMD) and reducing fracture risk.
  • Postmenopausal women with osteoporosis and risk factors such as sedentary lifestyle and history of smoking benefit significantly from bisphosphonate therapy.
  • While calcium and vitamin D are essential for bone health, they are not sufficient to treat established osteoporosis and are generally used as adjunct therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium + Vitamin D supplementation: Although calcium and vitamin D are important for bone health, they are not sufficient to treat osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -2.5). They are typically used for prevention and adjunct therapy in individuals at risk for osteoporosis but cannot reverse existing bone loss.

 

Option C. Estrogen + Progesterone (Hormone Replacement Therapy - HRT): HRT can reduce bone loss in postmenopausal women but is not the first-line treatment for osteoporosis due to the associated risks of breast cancer, stroke, and cardiovascular events. Bisphosphonates are preferred due to their better safety profile.

 

Option D. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates new bone formation. It is typically used in cases of severe osteoporosis or when bisphosphonates are contraindicated or have failed. Given that this patient can be managed with bisphosphonates, teriparatide is not the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for postmenopausal women diagnosed with osteoporosis (T-score ≤ -2.5). 
  • These medications reduce bone resorption and increase bone density, significantly lowering fracture risk. 
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are essential adjunct therapies but are not sufficient as standalone treatment for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with repeated fire-setting behavior over the past year. He shows no remorse and has a history of lying and bullying other children. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conduct disorder

 

  • The adolescent displays a pattern of repeated fire-setting, deceitfulness (lying), bullying, and lack of remorse over a significant period (1 year), which fulfills the diagnostic criteria for Conduct Disorder. 
  • This condition is characterized by a persistent pattern of violating societal norms or the rights of others, often including aggression, property destruction, theft, and serious rule violations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oppositional defiant disorder: Involves argumentative, defiant, and hostile behavior, especially toward authority figures, but does not include severe behaviors like fire-setting or cruelty seen in conduct disorder.

 

Option C. Pyromania: Pyromania involves deliberate fire-setting driven by fascination or gratification, and the act is typically not associated with anger or criminal behavior. In this case, fire-setting is part of a broader pattern of antisocial behavior.

 

Option D. Intermittent explosive disorder: Characterized by impulsive, aggressive outbursts that are disproportionate to provocation but it does not involve premeditated behaviors like lying or bullying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Conduct disorder is characterized by a persistent pattern of ‘disregard for rights of others’ and aggressive and dissocial behaviour, and manifests with the following:
    • Stealing, repeated lying, aggression, bullying, cruelty towards animals, disobedience, running away from school
    • High risk of later development of antisocial personality disorder

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with burning pain and paresthesias in the plantar aspect of the foot, radiating to the toes. Symptoms are worse with prolonged standing and walking. Which nerve is most likely compressed in tarsal tunnel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior tibial nerve

 

  • The posterior tibial nerve passes through the tarsal tunnel, a narrow passageway located on the inside of the ankle, behind the medial malleolus. 
  • Tarsal tunnel syndrome occurs when this nerve is compressed within the tunnel. 
  • Symptoms include pain, numbness, tingling, and burning sensations in the ankle, heel, and sole of the foot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve provides sensation to the lateral aspect of the thigh. It is involved in meralgia paresthetica, a condition causing tingling, numbness, and pain in the outer thigh. 

 

Option C. Common peroneal nerve: This nerve branches off the sciatic nerve and wraps around the fibular neck. It innervates muscles in the lateral and anterior compartments of the leg and provides sensation to the lateral leg and the dorsum of the foot. Compression of the common peroneal nerve can cause foot drop and sensory deficits.

 

Option D. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, originating in the lower back and extending down the back of the leg. It branches into the tibial and common peroneal nerves. While the posterior tibial nerve branches from the sciatic, the sciatic nerve itself is not contained within the tarsal tunnel. Sciatica refers to pain along the path of the sciatic nerve, which is a different condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tarsal tunnel syndrome specifically involves compression of the posterior tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel.

questions.text: A 28-year-old traveler recently returned from West Africa and presents with high-grade fever, chills, and sweating. A peripheral blood smear is sent to the lab and shows ring forms of Plasmodium falciparum, but no schizonts or late trophozoite stages are observed. Which of the following best explains why these stages are typically absent in the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They are sequestered in capillaries due to adherence to endothelium

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is unique among malarial species in that its late trophozoite and schizont stages adhere to the capillary endothelium, a process called cytoadherence.
  • This adherence to endothelial cells leads to sequestration of infected red blood cells in deep vascular beds, particularly in the brain, lungs, and other vital organs.
  • As a result, these stages are not typically seen in the peripheral blood smear, and only early ring forms and gametocytes are visible.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Antibody-dependent cytotoxic killing: This describes immune mechanisms involved in parasite clearance, but it does not explain the specific absence of schizonts and late trophozoites of P. falciparum from peripheral blood.

 

Option B. Seen only in mosquito stages of the parasite: Incorrect. Schizonts and late trophozoites are part of the human erythrocytic cycle, not restricted to mosquito stages. Mosquito stages include sporozoites and gametocytes.

 

Option D. They are filtered out by splenic sequestration: While the spleen does remove abnormal RBCs and plays a role in parasite clearance, the specific absence of schizonts in P. falciparum is due to vascular endothelium adherence, not splenic filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Plasmodium falciparum infections, schizonts and late trophozoites are not seen in peripheral blood smears due to their adherence to capillary endothelium and sequestration in deep vascular beds.

questions.text: Match the following oncogenes and cell cycle regulators with the associated malignancies:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–4, B–3, C–1, D–2

 

A. N-MYC → 4. Neuroblastoma

 

  • N-MYC is an oncogene that encodes a transcription factor.
  • It is often amplified in neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.
  • The degree of N-MYC amplification correlates with poor prognosis.
  • High-yield association: N-MYC → Neuroblastoma.

 

B. L-MYC → 3. Lung carcinoma (small cell)

 

  • L-MYC is another MYC family transcription factor, similar to c-MYC and N-MYC.
  • It is most notably associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung, a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor.
  • L-MYC is amplified in this malignancy, promoting unregulated cell proliferation.
  • High-yield association: L-MYC → Small cell lung carcinoma.

 

C. CCND1 (Cyclin D1) → 1. Mantle cell lymphoma

 

  • Cyclin D1, encoded by the CCND1 gene, regulates the G1→S transition of the cell cycle.
  • In mantle cell lymphoma, a t(11;14) translocation places CCND1 under the influence of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) promoter, leading to overexpression.
  • This drives uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • Classic board association: t(11;14) → CCND1 → Mantle cell lymphoma.

 

D. CDK4 → 2. Melanoma

 

  • CDK4 is a cyclin-dependent kinase that works with cyclin D1 to phosphorylate RB protein and advance the cell cycle.
  • Amplification or mutation of CDK4 is observed in several cancers, particularly melanoma.
  • This leads to unchecked cell division.
  • High-yield point: CDK4 → Melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • N-MYC → Neuroblastoma
  • L-MYC → Small cell lung carcinoma
  • CCND1 → Mantle cell lymphoma (via t(11;14))
  • CDK4 → Melanoma

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with recently diagnosed HIV presents with progressive shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and low-grade fever for 10 days. His oxygen saturation decreases on exertion. Chest imaging shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates, and bronchoalveolar lavage reveals organisms staining positive with silver stain. Which organism is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

  • This patient with AIDS and classic respiratory symptoms is presenting with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), a common opportunistic infection in patients with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm³.

 

Histopathological features include:

 

  • Diffuse interstitial pneumonitis (mononuclear infiltrates)
  • Foamy, eosinophilic material filling the alveoli, representing organisms and exudate
  • Organisms are typically identified on silver stain (GMS) as cup-shaped cysts

 

This foamy alveolar exudate is diagnostic and helps distinguish PJP from other pneumonias.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC): Typically causes systemic symptoms like fever, weight loss, and diarrhea in advanced AIDS. It is not associated with diffuse pulmonary infiltrates or silver-staining cysts.

 

Option C. Klebsiella pneumoniae: More likely in alcoholics or diabetics, presenting with productive cough and currant jelly sputum. Imaging often shows lobar consolidation, not bilateral diffuse infiltrates.

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis: A dimorphic fungus found in the southwestern U.S., typically causing community-acquired pneumonia. It does not stain with silver stain like Pneumocystis, and presents differently from PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia shows diffuse interstitial pneumonitis with foamy intra-alveolar exudates, and organisms are visualized with silver stain in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the otolaryngology clinic. Otoscopic examination reveals a picture as shown below. Identify the marked structure (Blue arrow)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chorda tympani

 

The chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that traverses through the middle ear. It runs between the malleus and the incus, crossing the tympanic cavity before exiting the skull through the petrotympanic fissure to join the lingual nerve. It carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and provides parasympathetic innervation to the submandibular and sublingual glands.

 

Key Observations Supporting the Identification:

 

  • The tympanic membrane (eardrum) is a thin, pearly white membrane that separates the external and middle ear.
  • The marked structure crossing the tympanic membrane horizontally is the chorda tympani nerve.
  • This structure does not appear as a bony ossicle like the malleus, incus, or stapes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Incus: The incus is one of the three middle ear ossicles and does not appear as a thin cord-like structure. It articulates with the malleus and stapes rather than crossing the tympanic membrane.

 

Option C. Stapes: The stapes is another ossicle of the middle ear, located further medially, connecting to the oval window. It does not traverse the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Malleus: The handle of the malleus is visible as a vertical structure attached to the tympanic membrane, ending at the umbo. However, it does not resemble the thin, horizontal structure observed in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chorda tympani nerve is a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that runs through the middle ear, crossing the tympanic membrane between the malleus and incus. It plays a crucial role in taste sensation and parasympathetic innervation of the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents after collapsing during a rugby match. He has since regained consciousness. On examination, he has a jerky carotid pulse and an ejection systolic murmur.

 

Investigations:

 

  • ECG Shown below: 

 

 

What is the most likely inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM), an autosomal dominant condition characterized by:
  • Syncope or sudden cardiac arrest during exertion due to arrhythmias or obstruction of left ventricular outflow.
  • Jerky carotid pulse due to impaired cardiac output.
  • Ejection systolic murmur, which increases with maneuvers like the Valsalva maneuver.

 

ECG Findings in HOCM:

 

  • Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH): Voltage criteria met for LVH.
  • T wave inversion in precordial leads (V1–V5): Suggestive of strain pattern due to hypertrophy.
  • Deep Q waves in inferior/lateral leads (III, aVF): Caused by hypertrophy of the interventricular septum.

 

Genetics of HOCM:

 

  • HOCM is caused by mutations in genes encoding sarcomeric proteins (e.g., MYH7 or MYBPC3).
  • The inheritance pattern is autosomal dominant, with variable penetrance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive: Rarely associated with sarcomeric protein mutations. Autosomal recessive patterns are more common in metabolic cardiomyopathies, such as Pompe disease, not HOCM.

 

Option C. Mitochondrial: Mitochondrial inheritance typically causes cardiomyopathies associated with multisystem disorders (e.g., MELAS syndrome), not isolated HOCM.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant: Rare and usually associated with Fabry disease, which may cause LVH but lacks the characteristic findings of HOCM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HOCM is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by exertional syncope, LVH, and ECG changes (T wave inversion, deep Q waves). It is a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for evaluation of persistent vomiting and poor weight gain. The mother reports that the child vomits soon after every feed and has had fewer wet diapers. On examination, the child appears dehydrated and irritable. Laboratory findings reveal hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with a potassium level of 2.9 mEq/L. An abdominal ultrasound shows thickening of the pyloric muscle. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology behind this electrolyte abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of gastric secretions leading to hydrogen and chloride loss

 

  • This child has classic signs of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, presenting with projectile vomiting, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia. 
  • The vomiting causes loss of hydrogen and chloride ions from gastric contents, leading to metabolic alkalosis and secondary hypokalemia due to compensatory renal mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal renal tubular dysfunction leading to bicarbonate loss: It is incorrect because RTA would lead to metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis.

 

Option C. Aldosterone deficiency due to congenital adrenal hyperplasia: (CAH) presents with hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Pancreatic enzyme deficiency leading to fat malabsorption: Cystic fibrosis) leads to steatorrhea, not metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pyloric stenosis causes hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to repeated vomiting and loss of gastric hydrochloric acid.

Sparing of the tendinous insertion of the extraocular muscle
Enlarged lacrimal glands suggestive of glandular involvement

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a known history of hyperthyroidism presents with progressive bilateral proptosis, lid retraction, and restricted ocular movements. A CT scan of the orbits is performed to differentiate between thyroid eye disease and orbital inflammatory syndrome. Which of the following CT findings most specifically supports a diagnosis of thyroid-related orbitopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sparing of the tendinous insertion of the extraocular muscle

 

Thyroid eye disease (thyroid orbitopathy) is characterized on CT by enlargement of extraocular muscles, most often the inferior rectus, medial rectus, or superior rectus, with typical sparing of the tendinous insertions. This radiological sign is crucial in differentiating thyroid orbitopathy from orbital pseudotumor, which involves both the muscle belly and the tendon.

 

The sparing of the tendon reflects the selective autoimmune involvement of muscle fibers in thyroid eye disease, and it is a hallmark imaging finding that guides the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enlargement of the extraocular muscles with muscle belly thickening: Seen in both thyroid orbitopathy and orbital inflammatory syndrome, and therefore not specific for either condition on its own.

 

Option C. Enlarged lacrimal glands suggestive of glandular involvement: More indicative of orbital inflammatory diseases, sarcoidosis, or lymphoproliferative disorders, not specific to thyroid orbitopathy.

 

Option D. Presence of periorbital edema with soft tissue swelling around the eyelids: A nonspecific sign that can be present in many orbital disorders, including thyroid eye disease, but does not distinguish it from orbital pseudotumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In thyroid orbitopathy, sparing of the tendinous insertion on CT imaging helps differentiate it from orbital inflammatory syndrome, which involves both muscle belly and tendon.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man from Bengaluru presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the back. He has a history of Marfan syndrome. On examination, he appears anxious and diaphoretic. His brachial pulses are weak bilaterally.

 

Vitals:

 

  • Blood Pressure: 180/100 mmHg (right arm)
  • Heart Rate: 112 bpm
  • Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths/min
  • SpO₂: 98% on room air

 

A CT angiogram shown below: 

 

 

What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous beta-blockers and blood pressure control

 

  • In acute Type A aortic dissection, the immediate goal is to reduce aortic shear stress. 
  • This is done through IV beta-blockers (like labetalol or esmolol) to rapidly lower heart rate (<60 bpm) and systolic BP (<120 mmHg). 
  • This initial stabilization is critical before proceeding to definitive surgical repair, especially in hypertensive and tachycardic patients like this one.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency surgical repair: Needed eventually, but without initial BP and HR control, surgery has higher risks.

 

Option B. High-dose corticosteroids: Used in vasculitic conditions, not aortic dissection.

 

Option C. Intravenous thrombolysis: Contraindicated in aortic dissection; may lead to catastrophic hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type A aortic dissection is a surgical emergency, but the first step in management is IV beta-blocker administration and blood pressure control to prevent extension or rupture. Always stabilize before surgery.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding renal stones is not true? 

 

  1.  Triple phosphate stones are common in patients with PCKD.
  2.  Stones can form in both acidic and alkaline urine.
  3.  Soft stones in the upper calyx can be removed by extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL).
  4.  RIRS is a type of endo-urological treatment for renal stones
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only statement 1 is not true

 

  • Oxalate and urate stones are common in patients with PCKD

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 2. Stones can form in both acidic and alkaline urine: Correct – Triple phosphate stones form in alkaline urine while oxalate form in acidic urine

 

Statement 3. Soft stones in the upper calyx can be removed by extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Correct – ESWL is useful for soft, non-lower calyceal stones up to 2 cm.

 

Statement 4. RIRS is a type of endo-urological treatment for renal stones: Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) is a type of endoscopic treatment for renal stones.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Renal stones are associated with pre-existing conditions like Polycystic kidney disease. 
  • They are formed in acidic urine or alkaline urine, depending on the type. ESWL and RIRS are minimally invasive treatments for renal stones up to 2 cm.

choices.text: Secretion of serotonin directly into the systemic venous circulation
Overproduction of gastrin causing vasodilation and diarrhea
Loss of serotonin metabolism by monoamine oxidase in the lung
Escape of serotonin into systemic circulation due to hepatic metastasis

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with episodic flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing. Physical examination reveals a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) levels. Imaging reveals a polypoid mass in the small bowel with metastases to the liver. Which of the following best explains the appearance of her systemic symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Escape of serotonin into systemic circulation due to hepatic metastasis

 

  • This clinical scenario is best identified as a carcinoid tumor based on the following distinctive features given in the question
  • Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant neuroendocrine tumors, often arising in the small bowel and secreting serotonin.
  • Normally, serotonin secreted into the portal circulation is metabolized by liver monoamine oxidase (MAO) to 5-HIAA, which is excreted in urine.
  • When the tumor metastasizes to the liver, serotonin can bypass hepatic metabolism and enter the systemic circulation, leading to carcinoid syndrome (flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm).
  • Additionally, carcinoid heart disease typically affects the right side of the heart due to exposure to circulating serotonin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secretion of serotonin directly into the systemic venous circulation: Incorrect; Serotonin enters systemic circulation after liver metabolism fails, not directly from gut to systemic blood.

 

Option B. Overproduction of gastrin causing vasodilation and diarrhea: Incorrect; This describes Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, not carcinoid tumor.

 

Option C. Loss of serotonin metabolism by monoamine oxidase in the lung: Incorrect; Monoamine oxidase in the liver, not the lungs, is responsible for initial metabolism of serotonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carcinoid syndrome occurs when serotonin-secreting tumors metastasize to the liver, bypassing hepatic degradation and releasing serotonin into systemic circulation—manifesting as flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and right-sided heart disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with secondary infertility and a history of two prior pregnancy losses managed with dilation and curettage (D&C). She reports irregular, light menstrual periods since her last miscarriage. Hysteroscopy is performed, revealing thin, fibrous intrauterine adhesions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

  • This patient presents with Asherman’s syndrome (intrauterine adhesions), which is characterized by secondary infertility and menstrual abnormalities following uterine trauma (e.g., D&C, infections, or uterine surgery).
  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the first-line treatment, involving the surgical removal of adhesions to restore the normal uterine cavity and improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopic septal resection: Incorrect. Septal resection is indicated for uterine septa (congenital anomalies), not adhesions. The hysteroscopy image shows adhesions, not a septum.

 

Option C. In-vitro fertilization (IVF): Incorrect. IVF is an option for infertility but does not address the primary issue (adhesions). Restoring the uterine cavity with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is preferred first.

 

Option D. Tubal recanalization: Incorrect. Tubal recanalization is for blocked fallopian tubes, not intrauterine adhesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman’s syndrome) are a common cause of secondary infertility and menstrual irregularities after uterine trauma (e.g., D&C). 
  • Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment of choice to restore the uterine cavity and improve fertility.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Asperger Syndrome are true? 

 

  1. It is more common in girls than in boys.
  2. Early language development in syntax and semantics is typically normal.
  3. Affected children may have a narrow and intense range of interests that interfere with social adaptation.
  4. Children may exhibit inappropriate prosody and not adjust their speech to the setting.
  5. Higher-order social and pragmatic language impairments are uncommon in this disorder.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3 and 4 only

 

Statement 2 – True: Children typically have normal early language development, especially syntax and semantics.

 

Statement 3 – True: They often have circumscribed, intense interests that interfere with learning and social interaction.

 

Statement 4 – True: Prosody and speech modulation (intonation, rate, volume) may be inappropriate to social context.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 1 – False: Asperger syndrome is more common in boys, not girls.

 

Statement 5 – False: Higher-order social and language pragmatic impairments are common as children mature.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Asperger syndrome presents with normal early language development but is characterized by impaired social interaction, restricted interests, and inappropriate prosody. 
  • It is more common in boys and may involve circumscribed preoccupations that hinder adaptive functioning.

choices.text: Spindle cells arranged in Antoni A and Antoni B patterns
Small round blue cells with scant cytoplasm

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. MRI with gadolinium contrast reveals an image as shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spindle cells arranged in Antoni A and Antoni B patterns

 

Vestibular schwannomas (also called acoustic neuromas) are benign tumors of Schwann cells, most commonly affecting the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. They often present with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance. The gold standard investigation is MRI with gadolinium, which shows a cerebellopontine angle mass.

 

Histopathology reveals:

 

  • Antoni A areas: Highly cellular, spindle-shaped cells arranged in palisading fashion forming Verocay bodies.
  • Antoni B areas: Hypocellular, loose myxoid regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudorosettes and Homer-Wright rosettes: Seen in medulloblastoma or neuroblastoma, not vestibular schwannoma.

 

Option C. Small round blue cells with scant cytoplasm: Classic of Ewing’s sarcoma or neuroblastoma, not schwannoma.

 

Option D. Epithelioid cells with caseating granulomas: Characteristic of tuberculosis, not a tumor.

 

Educational Objective:


Vestibular schwannomas exhibit characteristic histopathology with Antoni A (Verocay bodies) and Antoni B patterns, aiding in definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with long-standing diabetic gastroparesis is started on a prokinetic agent to improve gastric emptying. The chosen drug stimulates gastrointestinal motility but does not exert dopamine D2 receptor antagonism, thus avoiding extrapyramidal side effects. Which of the following agents best fits this profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cisapride

 

  • Cisapride is a prokinetic drug that enhances gastrointestinal motility by stimulating 5-HT4 (serotonin) receptors and increasing acetylcholine release at the myenteric plexus.
  • Importantly, it lacks dopamine D2 receptor antagonistic action, and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal side effects.
  • Though effective, its use has been largely restricted due to the risk of QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoclopramide: A D2 receptor antagonist with prokinetic and antiemetic properties. Can cause extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., dystonia, tardive dyskinesia).

 

Option B. Itopride: Although primarily a D2 antagonist, it also has acetylcholinesterase inhibitory activity. While it has a better CNS safety profile than metoclopramide, it still has D2 antagonistic action.

 

Option D. Chlorpromazine: A typical antipsychotic with D2 blocking effects, occasionally used for nausea/vomiting, but not used as a primary prokinetic and has significant CNS side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cisapride is a prokinetic agent that lacks D2 receptor antagonism, instead acting through 5-HT4 receptor stimulation to enhance gastrointestinal motility.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child collapses in the emergency department waiting room. Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) protocol is initiated for cardiac arrest. The team begins CPR and prepares medications for administration. Which of the following statements regarding drug administration in pediatric cardiac arrest is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine initial dose is 0.1 mg/kg rapid IV bolus with a max of 6 mg

 

Adenosine is the first-line drug used for stable supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) in children. The initial dose is 0.1 mg/kg IV rapid bolus with a maximum first dose of 6 mg. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The correct epinephrine dose is 1 mg IV/IO every 3–5 minutes regardless of weight: The correct dose of epinephrine in pediatric cardiac arrest is 0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000) IV/IO every 3–5 minutes. The fixed 1 mg dose is used in adults, not children.

 

Option B. Amiodarone can be given at a dose of 6 mg/kg IV/IO: The correct dose of amiodarone during pediatric pulseless arrest is 5 mg/kg IV/IO bolus. A 6 mg/kg dose is not recommended.

 

Option D. Atropine is administered at 0.1 mg/kg IV/IO as a single dose: Atropine is administered at 0.02 mg/kg IV/IO in children for bradycardia, not 0.1 mg/kg. 

 

Educational Objective:


In pediatric cardiac arrest, medication dosages are weight-based. Adenosine is used for SVT at an initial dose of 0.1 mg/kg (max 6 mg), unlike epinephrine which is dosed at 0.01 mg/kg.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lateral border of the tongue undergoes neck imaging, which shows ipsilateral level II cervical lymphadenopathy. The surgical team decides to proceed with a modified radical neck dissection. Which cervical lymph node levels are included in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Submental, submandibular, deep cervical, posterior triangle

 

Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND) involves:

 

  • Removal of all lymph node groups from Level I to Level V
  • Preservation of one or more non-lymphatic structures, such as:
    • Spinal accessory nerve (SAN)
    • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
    • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM)

 

Level I: Submental (Ia) and submandibular (Ib) nodes.

 

Level II: Upper jugular nodes (superior to the hyoid bone).

 

Level III: Middle jugular nodes (between the hyoid bone and the cricoid cartilage).

 

Level IV: Lower jugular nodes (inferior to the cricoid cartilage).

 

Level V: Posterior triangle nodes (including supraclavicular nodes).

 

Level VI: Anterior compartment nodes (pretracheal and paratracheal).

 

Level VII: Mediastinal nodes (not always included in neck classifications). 

 

  • Preservation of one or more non-lymphatic structures, such as:
    • Spinal accessory nerve (SAN)
    • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
    • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM)

 

This procedure aims to preserve function while still providing oncologic control of nodal metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Modified radical neck dissection includes levels I to V cervical lymph nodes, with preservation of one or more of the accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid muscle, or internal jugular vein, and is performed to manage cervical metastases while reducing functional morbidity.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with:

 

  • Recurrent nosebleeds and heavy menstrual bleeding for 6 months
  • Multiple petechiae and bruises over the arms and legs

 

Investigations:

 

  • Haemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
  • White cell count: 2,200 cells/mm³
  • Platelets: 34 × 10⁹/L
  • Bone marrow biopsy: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aplastic anaemia

 

  • The patient's symptoms of recurrent epistaxis, heavy menstrual bleeding, petechiae, and bruises, along with pancytopenia (low haemoglobin, low white cell count, and low platelet count) and a hypocellular marrow on biopsy, strongly suggest aplastic anaemia. Here's why:
  • Aplastic anaemia is a condition characterized by bone marrow failure, where the bone marrow is unable to produce enough blood cells, leading to pancytopenia (reduced red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets). This leads to symptoms such as fatigue, easy bruising, bleeding tendencies, and petechiae.
  • A hypocellular marrow with fatty infiltrates is a key finding in aplastic anaemia. The bone marrow biopsy shows a lack of hematopoietic cells, which are replaced by fat cells, leading to bone marrow failure.
  • To diagnose aplastic anaemia, at least two of the following peripheral cytopenias must be present:
    • Haemoglobin <10.0 g/dL
    • Platelets <50 × 10⁹/L
    • Absolute neutrophil count <1.5 × 10⁹/L

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: G6PD deficiency typically causes hemolytic anemia, often triggered by infections, medications, or foods (such as fava beans). The patient's presentation of pancytopenia (including low white blood cells and platelets) and hypocellular marrow is not typical for G6PD deficiency, which primarily affects red blood cells and causes hemolysis.

 

Option C. Fanconi anaemia: Fanconi anaemia is a genetic disorder that leads to bone marrow failure and congenital abnormalities, but it typically presents earlier in life, often with short stature, skeletal abnormalities, and skin pigmentation changes. This patient's age (38 years) and presentation are more consistent with aplastic anaemia.

 

Option D. Iron-deficiency anaemia: Iron-deficiency anaemia is characterized by microcytic hypochromic anaemia and low serum ferritin, but it does not cause pancytopenia or a hypocellular bone marrow. In fact, the marrow in iron deficiency would typically show increased erythroid precursors, not fatty infiltration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aplastic anaemia is a serious condition characterized by bone marrow failure, leading to pancytopenia. It is associated with recurrent infections, bleeding tendencies, and fatigue.
  • Hypocellular marrow with fatty infiltrates on bone marrow biopsy is the hallmark of aplastic anaemia.
  • Treatment for aplastic anaemia may include immunosuppressive therapy, stem cell transplantation, or supportive care such as blood transfusions.

questions.text: Under India’s Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), various levels of disease reporting are followed to enable early detection and response to outbreaks. At the Primary Health Centre (PHC) level, which type of diagnosis is typically made by the Medical Officer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Probable case

 

  • In the IDSP reporting system, three levels of diagnosis are defined:
    1. Syndromic diagnosis – Based on symptoms alone, reported by health workers, ANMs, or peripheral workers.
    2. Probable diagnosis – Made by medical officers at PHC level based on clinical findings, without laboratory confirmation.
    3. Laboratory-confirmed diagnosis – Requires specific lab tests done at designated diagnostic centers.
  • Thus, PHC Medical Officers typically classify patients as probable cases, based on their clinical judgment and examination findings.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confirmed case: Requires lab confirmation and is not determined by PHC doctors unless lab reports are available.

 

Option C. Laboratory diagnosis: Requires diagnostic testing, usually done at district or referral laboratories, not at PHC level.

 

Option D. Syndromic diagnosis: This level is used by field-level workers who report based on symptom patterns—not by medical officers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under IDSP, PHC Medical Officers classify patients as probable cases based on clinical diagnosis without laboratory confirmation.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman from Chennai, recently diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma, presents to the emergency department with generalised weakness, reduced urine output, and increasing confusion over the past 24 hours. She had completed her first cycle of chemotherapy two weeks ago. On examination, she is lethargic, mildly dehydrated, and shows no signs of active infection.

Investigations:

  • Serum potassium: 5.2 mEq/L 
  • Serum calcium: 8.6 mg/dL 
  • Serum uric acid: 8.3 mg/dL 
  • Serum creatinine: 1.35 mg/dL 

What can be given to prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allopurinol

 

  • The patient’s presentation with fatigue, generalized weakness, oliguria, and confusion, along with hyperkalaemia, hypocalcaemia, hyperuricaemia, and elevated creatinine, strongly suggests tumour lysis syndrome (TLS). 
  • Here's why allopurinol is the most appropriate prophylactic treatment:
  • Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a life-threatening condition that can occur after the treatment of rapidly proliferating cancers, such as Burkitt lymphoma. It results from the massive release of intracellular contents from dying tumour cells, leading to:
    • Hyperuricaemia (from purine breakdown)
    • Hyperkalemia (from intracellular potassium release)
    • Hyperphosphatemia (from phosphate release)
    • Hypocalcaemia (due to calcium binding to phosphate)
  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces uric acid production by blocking the conversion of purines to uric acid. This helps prevent the buildup of uric acid in the kidneys, which can lead to uric acid nephropathy and worsen renal failure in TLS. Allopurinol is commonly used prophylactically in patients with high-risk cancers undergoing chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections, but it is not indicated for the prevention or management of tumour lysis syndrome, which is a metabolic complication, not an infection.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to treat fluid retention or oedema, but it would not be helpful in tumour lysis syndrome. In fact, diuretics should be used cautiously in TLS due to the risk of worsening renal function and electrolyte imbalances. The treatment focuses on correcting the underlying metabolic disturbances (e.g., using allopurinol for uric acid).

 

Option D. Piperacillin-tazobactam: Piperacillin-tazobactam is an antibiotic used for infections, and there is no evidence of an active infection in this patient. The primary issue here is tumour lysis syndrome, which is not treated with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumour lysis syndrome (TLS) is a potentially fatal complication of chemotherapy for highly proliferative cancers like Burkitt lymphoma. It results from the rapid breakdown of tumour cells, leading to hyperuricaemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcaemia.
  • Allopurinol is the treatment of choice to prevent TLS by inhibiting uric acid production and preventing renal complications.
  • Hydration and monitoring of electrolytes and renal function are also essential in managing TLS.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after ingesting a large quantity of over-the-counter acetaminophen in a suicide attempt. She is alert, but labs reveal mildly elevated liver enzymes. The medical team initiates treatment to prevent progression to hepatic central lobularnecrosis, the hallmark of acetaminophen toxicity. Which of the following agents is most effective if administered within the first few hours of ingestion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) N-acetylcysteine

 

  • Acetaminophen is primarily metabolized in the liver. In overdose, the normal conjugation pathways are saturated, and more drug is converted by CYP450 enzymes into a toxic intermediate: NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine).
  • NAPQI binds to hepatocellular proteins and causes central lobular (zone III) hepatic necrosis.
  • N-acetylcysteine (NAC) acts as a glutathione precursor and substitute, detoxifying NAPQI.
  • NAC is most effective when given within 8 hours, but benefit may still exist up to 24 hours post-ingestion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium nitrite: Used in cyanide poisoning as it induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide. It has no role in acetaminophen overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: A chelating agent used in arsenic, gold, and lead poisoning. It does not interact with acetaminophen or NAPQI.

 

Option D. Sodium thiosulfate: Also used in cyanide poisoning, as a sulfur donor in conversion to thiocyanate. It does not reverse acetaminophen toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen overdose. It replenishes hepatic glutathione stores, allowing detoxification of NAPQI and preventing hepatic central lobular necrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with sudden-onset diplopia. Examination reveals a right-sided third cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly suggest the need for urgent neuroimaging to rule out a compressive lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pupil involvement

 

In diabetic patients, third nerve palsy is often due to microvascular ischemia, which spares the pupil because parasympathetic fibers are located peripherally in the oculomotor nerve and are less affected by ischemia.

 

However, pupil involvement suggests a compressive lesion, such as a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, which affects the superficial parasympathetic fibers first. This distinction is crucial, and pupil-involving third nerve palsy requires urgent neuroimaging (e.g., MRI/MRA or CT angiography) to rule out an aneurysm or mass lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impaired adduction: Common in third nerve palsy, including microvascular causes; not a red flag on its own.

 

Option B. Vertical diplopia: A nonspecific symptom that can occur with various cranial nerve palsies (e.g., IV or III), but not an urgent imaging trigger.

 

Option C. Nystagmoid jerks: Suggests cerebellar or vestibular dysfunction, not typically associated with isolated third nerve pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In third nerve palsy, pupil involvement indicates possible compressive etiology (e.g., aneurysm) and warrants immediate neuroimaging.

choices.text: In hot environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down.
In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down.
In cold environments, rigor mortis persists for more time due to faster decomposition.
In hot environments, rigor mortis persists for more time due to faster decomposition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the effect of environmental temperature on rigor mortis is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) In cold environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down.

 

Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles, which occurs due to ATP depletion and calcium influx in muscle cells after death. The onset and duration of rigor mortis are strongly influenced by ambient temperature:

 

  • In cold environments, the body cools quickly, and metabolic processes slow down, leading to a delayed onset of rigor mortis. However, the rigidity tends to persist longer because decomposition is also delayed.
  • In hot environments, the body decomposes faster, so rigor mortis sets in more rapidly and resolves sooner due to accelerated putrefaction.

 

Thus, Option B is the most accurate: cold slows metabolic processes, resulting in slower onset of rigor mortis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In hot environments, rigor mortis sets in slowly because the body’s metabolic processes are slowed down: Incorrect. Hot temperatures speed up metabolism and decomposition, causing faster onset of rigor mortis, not slower.

 

Option C. In cold environments, rigor mortis persists for more time due to faster decomposition: Incorrect. While rigor does persist longer in cold, it's due to slower decomposition, not faster.

 

Option D. In hot environments, rigor mortis persists for more time due to faster decomposition: Incorrect. Faster decomposition in heat causes earlier onset and quicker resolution of rigor mortis, not prolonged duration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cold environments slow metabolic processes, leading to a delayed onset of rigor mortis, while heat accelerates both onset and resolution due to faster decomposition.

questions.text:
Match the following lymph nodes with their associated anatomical location or clinical relevance: 

 

Column A (Lymph Node)

 

  1. Rotter’s nodes
  2. Rouvier nodes
  3. Delphian nodes
  4. Irish nodes

 

Column B (Associated Site/Significance)

 

  1. Nodes in left axilla 
  2. Interpectoral nodes 
  3. Pre-cricoid/pre-tracheal lymph nodes
  4. Retropharyngeal nodes
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

1. Rotter’s nodes → B. Interpectoral nodes

 

  • Rotter’s nodes are located between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, i.e., the interpectoral space.
  • These nodes are involved in breast cancer metastasis and are often assessed during modified radical mastectomy.

 

2. Rouvier nodes → D. Retropharyngeal nodes

 

  • Rouvier nodes are located in the retropharyngeal space, near the base of the skull.
  • Clinically relevant in nasopharyngeal carcinoma and upper aerodigestive tract tumors.

 

3. Delphian nodes → C. Pre-cricoid/pre-tracheal lymph nodes

 

  • Also called prelaryngeal nodes, these are situated just anterior to the cricoid cartilage.
  • Often involved in laryngeal and thyroid malignancies.
  • Their involvement is a poor prognostic sign, especially in thyroid cancer—hence the name "Delphian" (meaning "prophetic").

 

4. Irish nodes → A. Nodes in left axilla

 

  • Irish node is a left axillary lymph node that may be enlarged due to metastatic spread of gastric carcinoma.
  • Analogous to Virchow’s node (left supraclavicular node), but located in the axilla instead of the neck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotter’s nodes (1-B): Located between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, commonly involved in breast carcinoma spread.

 

Rouvier nodes (2-D): Retropharyngeal lymph nodes, significant in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Delphian nodes (3-C): Precricoid/prelaryngeal nodes, seen in thyroid/laryngeal malignancies.

 

Irish nodes (4-A): Left axillary nodes seen in gastric carcinoma spread

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with schizophrenia is being treated with haloperidol. Two weeks into therapy, he develops muscle stiffness, resting tremor, and a shuffling gait. He is alert and oriented, and his symptoms are consistent with drug-induced parkinsonism. The physician initiates a medication that acts as a centrally acting antimuscarinic agent. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed to alleviate this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benzhexol

 

  • Benzhexol (also known as Trihexyphenidyl) is a centrally acting anticholinergic used to treat drug-induced parkinsonism, a common extrapyramidal side effect (EPS) of typical antipsychotics like haloperidol.
  • It works by restoring the dopamine-acetylcholine balance in the basal ganglia, where dopamine blockade by antipsychotics leads to relative cholinergic overactivity.
  • It improves symptoms like tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia associated with EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Used for akathisia, not parkinsonism. It’s a beta-blocker and has no anticholinergic effects.

 

Option C. Valbenazine: A VMAT2 inhibitor used specifically for tardive dyskinesia, not for parkinsonian features.

 

Option D. Risperidone: An antipsychotic that can worsen extrapyramidal symptoms, not treat them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Benzhexol (Trihexyphenidyl) is a centrally acting anticholinergic drug used to manage drug-induced parkinsonism caused by dopamine-blocking antipsychotic medications.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a racing heartbeat occurring intermittently for 6 months. She has a history of thyrotoxicosis, managed with propranolol and carbimazole.

 

Investigations:

 

  • ECG – shown below: 

 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome

 

  • The patient’s symptoms and ECG findings are consistent with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a condition caused by the presence of an accessory conduction pathway (the Bundle of Kent).

 

Key ECG Features of WPW Syndrome:

 

  1. Short PR interval (<0.12 seconds) – Indicates premature ventricular excitation due to the accessory pathway bypassing the AV node.
  2. Delta wave (slurred upstroke of the QRS complex) – Seen in WPW due to early ventricular activation.
  3. Broad QRS complex (>0.12 seconds) – Caused by fusion of normal conduction and conduction through the accessory pathway.

 

Why WPW Syndrome?

 

  • The patient’s intermittent palpitations suggest a paroxysmal tachyarrhythmia.
  • WPW syndrome can cause AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) or atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
  • Thyrotoxicosis increases sympathetic tone, making tachyarrhythmias more likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation: Typically shows irregularly irregular rhythm with no P waves on ECG, which is not seen here.

 

Option B. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT): Regular narrow-complex tachycardia without the short PR interval or delta waves.

 

Option C. Torsades de pointes: Characterized by polymorphic broad QRS complexes with a twisting pattern, usually associated with a prolonged QT interval, not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is an accessory pathway disorder characterized by a short PR interval, delta waves, and broad QRS complexes. 
  • It can present with intermittent palpitations and is often triggered by increased sympathetic activity, such as in thyrotoxicosis.
