questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drainage of bile

 

  • The image shows a Kehr’s T-tube, which is primarily used for bile drainage following choledochotomy. 
  • It consists of a T-shaped rubber tube where the horizontal limb lies inside the common bile duct (CBD), and the vertical limb exits the body to drain bile externally.
  • This is done to prevent bile leakage from a freshly sutured CBD and to monitor the amount of bile output postoperatively.
  • It also allows for a T-tube cholangiogram to confirm CBD patency before tube removal (typically after 10–14 days once a fibrous tract forms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drainage of postoperative fluids: Typically done with closed suction drains like Jackson-Pratt or Penrose drains.

 

Option B. Suprapubic catheterization: Uses Foley or Malecots catheter

 

Option D. Drainage of pus: Pigtail catheters or corrugated drains are used for abscess drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kehr’s T-tube is used after choledochotomy to drain bile externally, prevent bile leakage, and evaluate ductal patency postoperatively via a cholangiogram before safe removal.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male complaints of pain bilateral knees (R > L). He has difficulty in climbing stairs, squatting, sitting cross legged. His quadriceps muscle is wasted. On right knee X-ray, there is subchondral sclerosis, tibial spine spiking, obliterated medial joint space and reduced lateral joint space. AHLBACK is grade 2 stage. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conservative treatment 

 

  • Increased bone density beneath the cartilage, a sign of osteoarthritis.
  • Bone spurs on the tibial spines, also indicative of osteoarthritis.
  • Narrowing of the joint space on the medial side, suggesting cartilage loss.
  • Narrowing of the joint space on the lateral side, suggesting cartilage loss.
  • AHLBACK classification system is used to grade osteoarthritis of the knee. 
  • Grade 2 indicates moderate osteoarthritis with significant joint space narrowing and some bone changes.
  • AHLBACK Classification grades the severity of osteoarthritis based on radiographic findings, particularly joint space narrowing. 
  • Conservative management is generally the first step for osteoarthritis, even in moderate stages.
  • Conservative Measures: 
    • Pain management (NSAIDs, acetaminophen).
    • Physical therapy (strengthening, range of motion exercises, especially for the quadriceps).
    • Weight loss (if applicable).
    • Activity modification.
    • Intra-articular injections (corticosteroids, hyaluronic acid).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arthroscopy: While it can be helpful for certain knee conditions, it's generally not the primary treatment for moderate osteoarthritis. Arthroscopy is less effective for generalized osteoarthritis, and more effective for meniscal tears.

 

Option C. Total Knee Replacement (TKR): TKR is typically reserved for severe osteoarthritis (AHLBACK grade 3 or 4) when conservative measures have failed, and the patient's quality of life is significantly impacted. While the patient has significant pain, conservative measures should be attempted first.

 

Option D. High Tibial Osteotomy (HTO): HTO is more appropriate for younger, active patients with unicompartmental (usually medial) osteoarthritis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient has moderate osteoarthritis, and conservative management is the appropriate first step.

questions.text: A government school in a rural area establishes a kitchen garden as part of its nutrition program. The school receives seeds, manure, and agricultural tools from an international agency to support local food production and improve children’s nutritional intake. Which agency is primarily responsible for this type of support under applied nutrition programs?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) UNICEF

 

  • UNICEF (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) plays a key role in child health and nutrition, especially in developing countries. 
  • Under Applied Nutrition Programs (ANPs), UNICEF supports school-based initiatives by providing seeds, manure, and gardening tools to promote kitchen gardening.
  • This effort enhances nutrition education, food security, and the quality of mid-day meals provided to schoolchildren, aiming to combat malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies through local food production.
  • UNICEF integrates health, education, and nutrition to promote holistic child development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. WHO: Focuses on global public health policy, disease surveillance, and technical guidance. It does not supply physical agricultural inputs like seeds or manure to schools.

 

Option B. UNDP: Involved in development planning, poverty reduction, and governance, but it does not directly support school nutrition gardening programs.

 

Option C. CARE: A humanitarian agency involved in food aid and relief, but in the context of school-based applied nutrition programs, UNICEF is the lead agency providing such inputs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • UNICEF supports school-based applied nutrition programs by providing resources like seeds and manure to promote kitchen gardening and improve child nutrition.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the breast clinic with a newly detected 2 cm firm, irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Mammography confirms a suspicious lesion, and a core needle biopsy reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. On physical examination, there is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. The surgical team plans for breast-conserving surgery and wants to evaluate the axilla preoperatively. An axillary ultrasound is ordered. Which of the following best represents the sensitivity of axillary ultrasound in identifying axillary lymph node metastases in clinically node-negative breast cancer patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50–60%

 

  • In patients with clinically node-negative breast cancer, preoperative axillary ultrasonography (USG) is commonly used to detect lymph node involvement.
  • The sensitivity of axillary ultrasound in identifying metastatic nodes ranges from 50–60%, as it can identify morphologic features such as:
    • Cortical thickening
    • Loss of fatty hilum
    • Round hypoechoic nodes
    • Increased peripheral vascularity
  • If any of these suspicious findings are seen, USG-guided FNAC or core needle biopsy is performed to confirm metastasis.
  • If biopsy confirms metastasis, axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) is indicated. If biopsy is negative or not performed, the patient may be considered for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Axillary ultrasound has a sensitivity of 50–60% in detecting axillary lymph node metastases in clinically node-negative breast cancer patients. 
  • It helps in selecting candidates for axillary biopsy or SLNB.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding teratogenic drug effects are true? 

 

  1. Lithium exposure during pregnancy is associated with Ebstein anomaly.
  2. Thalidomide is classically associated with phocomelia and limb malformations.
  3. Phenytoin increases the risk of neuroblastoma and bleeding due to vitamin K deficiency.
  4. Tetracycline causes hyperpigmentation of the skin and nephrotoxicity.
  5. Cocaine use during pregnancy can lead to microcephaly, IUGR, and behavioral disturbances.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Statement 1 – True: Lithium is known to cause Ebstein anomaly, a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve.

 

Statement 2 – True: Thalidomide causes phocomelia, where limbs are severely underdeveloped, along with other malformations.

 

Statement 3 – True: Phenytoin is associated with congenital anomalies, neuroblastoma, and bleeding due to vitamin K deficiency.

 

Statement 5 – True: Cocaine is a known teratogen causing microcephaly, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and behavioral issues due to vasoconstriction and placental insufficiency.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 4 – False: Tetracycline causes pigmentation of teeth, not skin, and leads to hypoplasia of enamel, not nephrotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Several commonly used medications are teratogenic and may lead to severe congenital malformations. 
  • Recognizing specific drug-malformation associations is crucial for both exam preparation and clinical counselling in obstetrics.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with high-grade fever, hypotension, and petechiae following a complicated delivery with retained products of conception. On examination, she is bleeding from her intravenous sites and has widespread bruising. Laboratory tests reveal:

 

  • ↓ Platelet count
  • ↑ PT and PTT
  • ↓ Fibrinogen
  • Elevated D-dimer
  • Presence of schistocytes on peripheral smear

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

 

  • DIC is a condition characterized by widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to microthrombi formation and consumption of clotting factors and platelets, followed by bleeding.

 

Classic lab features of DIC:

 

  • ↓ Platelet count (consumption thrombocytopenia)
  • ↑ PT and PTT (consumption of coagulation factors)
  • ↓ Fibrinogen (used up in clot formation)
  • ↑ D-dimer (marker of fibrinolysis and fibrin degradation)
  • Schistocytes on smear due to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)

 

Triggers of DIC include obstetric complications, sepsis, malignancy, and trauma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilia A: Usually presents with isolated ↑PTT, normal platelets, and no fibrin degradation products.

 

Option B. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP): Features MAHA and thrombocytopenia, but normal PT/PTT and no decrease in fibrinogen.

 

Option D. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): Causes isolated thrombocytopenia with normal PT, PTT, and fibrinogen levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DIC is characterized by thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer, and MAHA (schistocytes), often in the setting of sepsis, trauma, or obstetric complications.

questions.text: In enzyme kinetics, what is the velocity of an enzymatic reaction when the substrate concentration equals the Michaelis constant (Km)?
questions.solution:
Ans D) Half the Vmax

 

This means that when the substrate concentration equals Km, the reaction velocity is exactly half of Vmax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Half the substrate concentration: Incorrect. Km is a substrate concentration. The reaction velocity is not defined as a fraction of substrate concentration, but rather of Vmax.

 

Option B. Same as Vmax: Incorrect. The reaction reaches Vmax only when the substrate concentration is much higher than Km, effectively saturating the enzyme.

 

Option C. Quarter the Vmax: Incorrect. At [S] = 0.5 Km, velocity would be Vmax/3, not Vmax/4. The statement is mathematically inaccurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When substrate concentration equals Km, the reaction velocity is half of Vmax, as defined by the Michaelis-Menten equation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. CECT abdomen does not show any fluid collections or necrosis. Which of the following are not routinely required in managing the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotics 

 

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of mild acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, without evidence of necrosis. 
  • The management of acute pancreatitis involves supportive care, including pain management, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional support. 
  • Antibiotics are not recommended unless severe pancreatitis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystalloids: NS or RL can be used in resuscitation if dehydrated

 

Option C. Analgesics: NSAIDs are used initially to alleviate the pain

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feedings: If the patient is stable and pain is controlled, early initiation of oral feeding is recommended. This approach has been associated with a shorter hospital stay and lower complication rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In the management of acute pancreatitis, antibiotics are required in moderate or severe cases.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man from Lucknow presents with a 3-month history of low-grade fever, night sweats, and an unintentional weight loss of 6 kg. He also complains of a painless swelling in the right side of his neck, which has gradually increased in size. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender, mobile cervical lymph node. No hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A chest X-ray shown below.

 

 

An excisional lymph node biopsy is performed, and histopathology reveals diffuse proliferation of large atypical lymphoid cells, positive for CD20.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

 

  • This patient has constitutional "B" symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats) and lymphadenopathy, suggestive of lymphoma. 
  • The histopathological finding of large atypical lymphoid cells and CD20 positivity supports the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common subtype of Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). 
  • It typically presents with rapidly enlarging lymph nodes and systemic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: Characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells, CD15 and CD30 positivity—not CD20. Often presents in younger patients with contiguous lymph node spread.

 

Option C. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): Usually seen in older adults with lymphocytosis, often asymptomatic or with mild symptoms and small lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Follicular lymphoma: A slower-growing (indolent) NHL subtype, usually presents with generalized painless lymphadenopathy and is often CD10 and BCL2 positive, not rapidly progressive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma, presenting with rapidly progressive lymphadenopathy and systemic B symptoms. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed via lymph node biopsy showing large atypical lymphoid cells that are CD20 positive. Early recognition is vital, as DLBCL is aggressive but potentially curable with chemotherapy (e.g., R-CHOP regimen).

questions.text:
Match the following types of firearm injuries with their characteristic features? 

 

Types of Wounds:

 

  1. Contact wound
  2. Close-range wound
  3. Distant-range wound
  4. Exit wound

 

Features:

 

  1. Tattooing (stippling) present, but no muzzle imprint.
  2. Irregular, everted margins, usually larger than entry.
  3. Circular entry, inverted margin, grease collar, no tattooing.
  4. Muzzle imprint and blackening inside wound.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–4, B–1, C–3, D–2

 

  1. Contact wound → 4: Shows blackening inside the wound, often with a muzzle imprint, due to direct contact with the firearm.
  2. Close-range wound → 1: Characterized by tattooing (stippling) from unburnt gunpowder, but no muzzle mark as the gun is not in contact.
  3. Distant-range wound → 3: Displays a clean circular entry, inverted margin, and grease/abrasion collar, with no burning or tattooing.
  4. Exit wound → 2: Typically irregular, everted, and often larger than the entry wound, with no abrasion collar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Contact wound: Muzzle imprint + blackening inside the wound
  • Close-range wound: Tattooing (stippling) present, no muzzle mark
  • Distant-range wound: Clean circular entry with inverted margin and grease collar, no tattooing
  • Exit wound: Irregular, everted margins, usually larger than entry, no abrasion collar

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with dysphagia, describing a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat during meals. He also reports mild chest discomfort with exertion. His medical history is significant for Down syndrome and congenital heart disease. A vascular anomaly compressing the esophagus is suspected. Which of the following imaging modalities is most appropriate to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Computed tomography angiography

 

  • The above described condition is Dysphagia lusoria. 
  • It refers to difficulty swallowing due to external compression of the esophagus by a vascular anomaly—most commonly an aberrant right subclavian artery. 
  • These anomalies can compress the esophagus posteriorly and often present with progressive solid-food dysphagia and may be associated with congenital heart defects, especially in syndromic conditions like Down syndrome.
  • The most accurate and preferred imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis is Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA). 
  • It provides detailed visualization of the aortic arch and its branches, and helps identify any vascular rings or aberrant arteries causing extrinsic esophageal compression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest x-ray: May show indirect signs like tracheal deviation, but it is neither sensitive nor specific for detecting vascular anomalies.

 

Option B. Barium swallow: Can suggest external compression on the esophagus and may be used as a preliminary study, but it cannot confirm the exact vascular anatomy responsible for the compression.

 

Option C. Echocardiogram: Useful for evaluating structural heart defects, but it does not adequately visualize great vessel anatomy or extrinsic compression of the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing vascular anomalies such as an aberrant subclavian artery causing dysphagia lusoria.

choices.text: Decrease in depth because of the lung stretch receptor reflex
Increase in rate because of the increased activity of the dorsal respiratory group
Increase in depth because of the increased sympathetic activity

questions.text: Stimulating the cephalic end of a vagus nerve would causes the respiration to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in depth because of the lung stretch receptor reflex

 

  • The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) plays a critical role in respiratory control by carrying inhibitory sensory input from the lungs to the brainstem respiratory centers.
    1. Hering-Breuer Reflex:
      • The Hering-Breuer reflex is a protective pulmonary stretch receptor reflex that prevents overinflation of the lungs.
      • Pulmonary stretch receptors located in the smooth muscle of the airways send afferent signals via the vagus nerve to the medullary respiratory centers when the lungs inflate.
      • Stimulation of the cephalic end of a vagus nerve inhibits apneustic center, leading to less stimulation of DRG and decreases the lung inflation, tricking the brainstem into thinking the lungs are already fully expanded.
      • This inhibits inspiration and causes respiration to cease (apnea).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in rate because of the increased activity of the dorsal respiratory group:

 

  • The dorsal respiratory group (DRG) in the medulla is primarily responsible for the initiation and control of inspiration.
  • Vagal afferents do not directly stimulate the DRG; instead, they provide inhibitory input via stretch receptors.
  • Cutting the vagus nerve would lead to deeper, slower breathing, not an increased rate.

 

Option C. Increase in depth because of the increased sympathetic activity:

 

  • The vagus nerve carries parasympathetic fibers, not sympathetic fibers.
  • Sympathetic stimulation affects bronchodilation but does not primarily control respiratory rate or depth.
  • Respiratory depth is mainly controlled by central chemoreceptors and lung stretch receptors, not the sympathetic nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hering-Breuer reflex is mediated by pulmonary stretch receptors, which send inhibitory signals to the medullary respiratory center via the vagus nerve to prevent lung overinflation. 
  • Stimulating the cephalic end of a cut vagus nerve mimics excessive lung expansion, leading to inhibition of inspiration and respiratory arrest.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presents for a routine checkup. Which of the following changes is not observed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in blood viscosity

 

  • During pregnancy, blood viscosity decreases due to a larger increase in plasma volume compared to red cell mass (physiological hemodilution). 
  • This reduction in viscosity helps improve uteroplacental perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fall in serum iron concentration: This occurs due to the increased demand for iron during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, leading to a physiological state of iron deficiency if supplementation is not provided.

 

Option B. Increase in serum iron-binding capacity: Serum iron-binding capacity increases due to elevated levels of transferrin, reflecting the body’s adaptation to the increased iron demands of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Increase in blood oxygen-carrying capacity: Despite the decrease in hemoglobin concentration due to hemodilution, the total hemoglobin mass increases by 18–20%, leading to an overall increase in the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During pregnancy, blood viscosity decreases due to hemodilution, while serum iron concentration falls, iron-binding capacity increases, and blood oxygen-carrying capacity rises due to increased hemoglobin mass.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamo-columnar junction located proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding and what is the confirmatory test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sliding hernia, Oral contrast imaging

 

  • During an endoscopy, finding the squamo-columnar junction (also known as the Z-line) located proximally to its normal position near the gastroesophageal junction suggests a condition in which the stomach has moved upwards, implying a sliding hiatus hernia. 
  • The next test is oral contrast imaging like CT or Barium meal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sliding hernia, Esophageal manometry: Manometry is performed for identifying motility disorders of the esophagus. It may be used as an adjunct in hiatus hernia but not for confirmation.

 

Option B. Rolling hernia, Esophageal manometry and Option D. Rolling hernia, Oral contrast imaging: A rolling or paraesophageal hernia occurs when part of the stomach herniates through the diaphragm next to the esophagus but the gastroesophageal junction stays in its normal position, so it would not typically result in the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Sliding hernia is the condition most likely responsible for the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy, indicating the upward movement of the stomach through the hiatal opening.

questions.text: Match the following RBC shapes with their key histological feature:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

A - 3 (Basophilic stippling → Aggregates of rRNA remnants)

Seen in lead poisoning, thalassemia, and sideroblastic anemia due to impaired degradation of ribosomal RNA.

 

B - 1 (Howell-Jolly bodies → DNA remnants due to absent spleen function) Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants, seen in asplenia, sickle cell disease, and post-splenectomy states.

 

C - 4 (Pappenheimer bodies → Iron granules in mitochondria) Pappenheimer bodies are iron-laden granules, seen in sideroblastic anemia and post-splenectomy.

 

D - 2 (Cabot rings → Mitotic spindle remnants) Cabot rings are nuclear remnants, seen in megaloblastic anemia and myelodysplastic syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basophilic stippling is caused by rRNA remnants
  • Howell-Jolly bodies are DNA remnants seen post-splenectomy
  • Pappenheimer bodies contain iron granules
  • Cabot rings represent mitotic spindle remnants

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents for preconception counselling. She reports a history of two first-trimester miscarriages and a preterm delivery at 30 weeks due to severe preeclampsia. She is concerned about her future pregnancies and asks for an evaluation to determine the cause of her pregnancy complications. Which of the following investigations would be most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus anticoagulant

 

  • This patient’s history of recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss and severe preeclampsia leading to a preterm birth raises concern for Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA). 
  • APLA is an autoimmune condition characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL), which cause a hypercoagulable state leading to pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, preeclampsia, intrauterine growth restriction, and preterm delivery.
  • The diagnosis of APLA requires both clinical criteria (history of thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) and laboratory criteria (persistent presence of aPL on two occasions at least 12 weeks apart).
  • Laboratory tests for APLA include:
    • Lupus anticoagulant (most specific)
    • Anti-cardiolipin antibodies
    • Beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies
  • Since this patient meets the clinical criteria for APLA, testing for lupus anticoagulant is the most relevant next step in her evaluation. 
  • Early recognition and management of APLA are essential, as treatment with low-dose aspirin and heparin can significantly improve pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HbA1c: HbA1c is used to assess glycemic control in diabetes. While poorly controlled diabetes is associated with pregnancy complications such as congenital anomalies and preeclampsia, this patient’s recurrent pregnancy loss and severe preeclampsia are more suggestive of a thrombophilic disorder like APLA rather than diabetes. Therefore, testing HbA1c is not the most relevant investigation in this context.

 

Option C. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): Thyroid dysfunction, particularly hypothyroidism, can cause pregnancy complications, including miscarriage. However, thyroid disorders are not a common cause of early severe preeclampsia or recurrent first-trimester losses. Given the strong suspicion for APLA, testing TSH is not the most appropriate initial step.

 

Option D. TORCH screen: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other [syphilis, varicella], Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can cause congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and stillbirth, but they are not typically associated with recurrent early pregnancy loss or preeclampsia. Therefore, a TORCH screen is not the best test in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA) should be suspected in women with recurrent first-trimester miscarriages and severe preeclampsia leading to preterm delivery before 34 weeks. 
  • The diagnostic evaluation includes testing for lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin antibodies, and beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The treating physician decides to apply Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) to improve oxygenation. Following the adjustment, various physiological parameters are closely monitored to evaluate the effects of PEEP on the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status. What is one of the effects of applying PEEP (Positive End Expiratory Pressure) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

 

Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is used in mechanically ventilated patients to prevent alveolar collapse at the end of expiration. It works by maintaining positive pressure within the alveoli during expiration, which:

 

  • Improves oxygenation by keeping alveoli open
  • Recruits collapsed alveoli, increasing the surface area for gas exchange
  • Increases the functional residual capacity (FRC) — the volume of air remaining in the lungs after passive expiration

 

An increase in FRC helps to reduce intrapulmonary shunting and improves the ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, especially beneficial in conditions like ARDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased airway resistance: PEEP does not increase airway resistance. Airway resistance is more commonly influenced by bronchoconstriction, secretions, or endotracheal tube issues. PEEP works on alveolar pressure, not airway caliber.

 

Option C. Increase in cardiac output: PEEP increases intrathoracic pressure, which can reduce venous return to the heart, thereby decreasing cardiac output, especially at higher levels of PEEP.

 

Option D. Increased renal blood flow: PEEP can decrease renal perfusion due to reduced cardiac output and activation of neurohormonal responses (RAAS). This may lead to reduced urine output and fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:


PEEP improves oxygenation in ventilated patients primarily by increasing functional residual capacity (FRC), which helps prevent alveolar collapse and improves ventilation-perfusion matching.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents with dry mouth and an increased need to urinate. His medical history includes hypertension, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), and gout, managed with the following medications:

 

  • Amlodipine
  • Ramipril
  • Bendroflumethiazide
  • Omeprazole
  • Allopurinol

 

Investigations:

 

Fasting plasma glucose: 147.6 mg/dL

 

Oral glucose tolerance test (75 g), 2-hour plasma glucose: 172.8 mg/dL 

 

His general practitioner explains that he has impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and believes that one of his medications is causing this problem.

 

Which of his medications is likely to be causing this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorthiazide

 

  • The patient has developed impaired glucose tolerance (IGT), indicated by:
  • Elevated fasting plasma glucose: 147.6 mg/dL 
  • Elevated 2-hour plasma glucose on OGTT: 172.8 mg/dL
  • The most likely culprit is Hydrochlorthiazide, a thiazide diuretic, which is well-known to cause impaired glucose tolerance and hyperglycaemia.

 

How Hydrochlorthiazide Causes Impaired Glucose Tolerance:

 

  • Reduced insulin secretion: Thiazides impair glucose-stimulated insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells, contributing to hyperglycemia.
  •  Insulin resistance: Thiazides decrease glucose uptake in peripheral tissues by depleting potassium (hypokalaemia), which is essential for insulin release and glucose metabolism.
  • Increased hepatic glucose production: Thiazides indirectly increase gluconeogenesis.

 

Next Steps in Management:

 

  • Switch from Hydrochlorthiazide to an alternative antihypertensive:
    • ACE inhibitors (e.g., ramipril): Preferred in patients with diabetes or IGT.
    • Calcium channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine): Suitable for elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension.
  • Lifestyle modification: Dietary changes, exercise, and weight management to prevent progression to type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Monitor blood glucose levels regularly to evaluate for progression to diabetes.

 

Classification of Glucose Intolerance (WHO Criteria):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allopurinol (Xanthine oxidase inhibitor): Used to reduce uric acid in gout. Does not affect glucose metabolism. In fact, some studies suggest it may have a protective effect against diabetes.

 

Option B. Amlodipine (Calcium channel blocker): Commonly used for hypertension. Generally neutral for glucose metabolism and does not cause hyperglycemia.

 

Option D. Omeprazole (Proton pump inhibitor): Used for GORD and gastric protection. No known association with impaired glucose tolerance. In some cases, it may even reduce insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bendroflumethiazide is the most common antihypertensive associated with impaired glucose tolerance.
  • Thiazide diuretics cause hyperglycemia through:
    • Insulin resistance (due to hypokalaemia)
    • Reduced insulin release (from pancreatic beta cells)

questions.text: Match the following immunofluorescence (IF) patterns seen in glomerular diseases with the corresponding clinical conditions:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–2, B–3, C–1

 

A. Linear IF pattern → 2.Goodpasture syndrome
Caused by anti-GBM antibodies that bind linearly along the basement membrane.

 

B. Granular IF pattern → 3. PSGN or diffuse proliferative GN
Due to immune complex deposition, giving a granular "lumpy-bumpy" appearance.

 

C. Negative IF (pauci-immune) → 1. ANCA-associated vasculitides like
→ Wegener granulomatosis (GPA)
→ Microscopic polyangiitis
→ Churg-Strauss syndrome


These conditions lack significant immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different immunofluorescence patterns in glomerular disease help differentiate between immune complex diseases (granular), anti-GBM disease (linear), and ANCA-associated vasculitides (pauci-immune/negative IF).

1st tendon of Flexor digitorum superficialis

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked in the image below :
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st Lumbrical

 

The lumbrical muscles are intrinsic muscles of the hand that originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. These muscles are responsible for flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at the interphalangeal joints. In the image, the marked structure corresponds to the 1st lumbrical, which is located on the radial side of the 2nd finger and arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Key Features of Lumbricals:

 

  1. First and second lumbricals:
    • Unipennate muscles (fibers run in a single direction).
    • Innervated by the median nerve.
  2. Third and fourth lumbricals:
    • Bipennate muscles (fibers run in two directions).
    • Innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

In the image, the muscle marked is unipennate, confirming it as the 1st lumbrical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd Lumbrical: This muscle is also unipennate but located on the radial side of the 3rd finger. It is not marked in this image.

 

Option C. 1st tendon of Flexor digitorum profundus: This tendon gives rise to the 1st lumbrical, but the arrow points to the muscle, not the tendon.

 

Option D. 1st tendon of Flexor digitorum superficialis: This tendon is superficial and does not give rise to the lumbricals, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical is a unipennate muscle in the hand that arises from the radial side of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon of the 2nd finger and is innervated by the median nerve. It is crucial for coordinated finger movements.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) Supreme are true?

 

  1. It is a second-generation supraglottic airway device with a modified cuff and drainage tube.
  2. The fixation tab of LMA Supreme should rest approximately 4–5 cm above the upper lip for optimal placement.
  3. It allows for gastric access and reduces the risk of gastric aspiration.
  4. LMA Supreme is not suitable for laparoscopic procedures due to poor airway sealing.
  5. It features an integrated bite block and is single use.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 5

 

Statement 1 - True: The LMA Supreme is a second-generation supraglottic airway designed with a modified cuff and a drainage tube, which allows for better sealing and provides gastric access to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Statement 3 - True: It allows for gastric access via the drainage tube, which enables insertion of a gastric tube, thereby reducing aspiration risk.

 

Statement 5 – True: It is a single-use device and also includes an integrated bite block to prevent airway obstruction from patient biting.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2 – False: The fixation tab is generally aligned with the upper lip but the exact measurement (e.g., 4–5 cm above) is not a reliable indicator for optimal placement.

 

Statement 4 – False: Contrary to the statement, the LMA Supreme provides a better seal than earlier models and is suitable for laparoscopic procedures when used in appropriate patients.

 

Educational Objective:


The LMA Supreme is a second-generation supraglottic airway device used in short surgeries and situations where endotracheal intubation is not required. It improves safety by allowing gastric drainage and provides a better seal, making it appropriate even for certain laparoscopic procedures.

questions.text: A public health specialist is reviewing composite indices used to measure the overall well-being and development status of populations. One such index is the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). Which of the following components are included in calculating PQLI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Life expectancy at 1 year, infant mortality rate, literacy rate

 

  • The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a composite indicator developed to assess the quality of life or well-being of a population using non-economic measures. It includes:
    1. Life expectancy at age 1 year – avoids skew from high neonatal mortality
    2. Infant mortality rate (IMR) – reflects child survival and health systems
    3. Literacy rate – represents education and access to information
  • Each component is scored on a scale of 0 to 100, and the average of the three gives the final PQLI score. Income is intentionally excluded to focus on physical and social quality of life rather than economic wealth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Literacy rate, birth rate, life expectancy at birth: Incorrect – birth rate is not part of PQLI, and life expectancy at birth is not used; it uses life expectancy at age 1.

 

Option C. Life expectancy at birth, income, literacy rate: Describes the Human Development Index (HDI) components, not PQLI.

 

Option D. Life expectancy at birth, fertility rate, adult literacy rate: Incorrect - Life expectancy at 1 year, not birth, is used. Fertility rate is not a component of PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PQLI includes life expectancy at age 1, infant mortality rate, and literacy rate to assess physical quality of life, excluding income as a factor.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks of gestation is scheduled for labor induction. The obstetrician assesses the cervix using the Modified Bishop Score to determine the likelihood of successful induction. Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop Score?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Position of the fetal head

 

  • The Modified Bishop Score is used to assess cervical readiness for labor induction and predicts the likelihood of successful vaginal delivery. 
  • It includes five components:
    1. Cervical dilatation (0–10 cm)
    2. Cervical effacement (% of thinning)
    3. Station of the fetal head (how far the presenting part has descended into the pelvis)
    4. Position of the cervix (anterior, mid-position, or posterior)
    5. Cervical consistency (firm, medium, or soft)
  • The position of the fetal head (e.g., occiput anterior or posterior) is not included in the Bishop Score. Instead, it assesses station, which refers to how far the fetal head has descended into the birth canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Modified Bishop Score is used to determine the favorability of the cervix for labor induction. 
  • It includes cervical dilatation, effacement, station, cervical position, and consistency but does not include the fetal head position.

questions.text: A 12-month-old infant is brought for a routine well-baby checkup. The parents report that the child can stand without support, uses a pincer grasp to pick up small objects, imitates simple sounds, and kisses on request. Which of the following developmental milestones, if absent, would not be considered delayed for this age group?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uses three-word sentences

 

  • This is a developmental milestone typically seen around 24 months. 
  • At 12 months, the expected language includes 2–3 words with meaning. 
  • Thus, the use of 3-word sentences at 12 months would be advanced, not expected — if present, it’s above age expectations; if absent, it is not delayed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bear walking and cruising: These are expected motor milestones by 12 months. Cruising (walking while holding onto furniture) and bear walking (walking with arms and legs straight) are normal gross motor findings.

 

Option C. Releases objects voluntarily: This fine motor skill should be present by 12 months. Absence of this skill indicates fine motor delay.

 

Option D. Plays a simple ball game: This is a social and adaptive milestone expected by 12 months. Absence of this milestone suggests a delay in the social domain.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • At 12 months of age, expected developmental milestones include standing without support, cruising, using a mature pincer grasp, saying 2–3 meaningful words, imitating sounds, and engaging in simple interactive games like ball play or kissing on request. 
  • Skills beyond these, such as speaking in sentences, are not expected and their absence does not indicate delay.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics requires co-administration with cilastatin to maintain its efficacy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic effective against many gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic bacteria.
  • However, when administered alone, it is rapidly inactivated by renal dehydropeptidase I, an enzyme located in the brush border of renal tubular cells.
  • To prevent this enzymatic degradation, cilastatin is co-administered.
    • Cilastatin is not an antibiotic, but a dehydropeptidase I inhibitor, and is used only with imipenem to prolong its half-life and efficacy.
  • Therefore, imipenem + cilastatin is the standard combination for clinical use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: A third-generation cephalosporin that does not require cilastatin for protection. It is eliminated through the biliary and renal routes and is stable against many beta-lactamases.

 

Option C. Tazobactam: Not an antibiotic alone but a beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is combined with piperacillin to extend spectrum but does not require cilastatin for efficacy.

 

Option D. Aztreonam: A monobactam antibiotic used primarily against gram-negative bacteria. It is not degraded by renal dehydropeptidase and does not require cilastatin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that requires co-administration with cilastatin to inhibit renal dehydropeptidase I and prevent its inactivation in the kidney.

questions.text: A global epidemiological study known as the MONICA Project, coordinated by the World Health Organization. Which of the following best describes the primary objective of this project?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monitoring of trends and risk factors for cardiovascular disease

 

  • The MONICA Project (Multinational MONItoring of trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) was a WHO-led observational study conducted in 21 countries. 
  • Its goal was to track trends in cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and mortality and to analyze how changes in risk factors like hypertension, smoking, obesity, and cholesterol influenced those trends.
  • It provided valuable insights into global cardiovascular health, and unlike interventional studies, MONICA focused solely on data collection and surveillance to inform future public health strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Evaluation of cholesterol-lowering interventions in heart disease: Refers to the Lipid Research Clinics Coronary Primary Prevention Trial, which studied effects of lowering LDL—not related to MONICA.

 

Option B. Dietary and smoking behavior interventions for cardiovascular prevention: Describes the Oslo Diet-Heart Study, which tested behavior changes, not trend monitoring.

 

Option D. Community-based trials targeting cardiovascular risk reduction: Implies an interventional design, which MONICA was not. It did not test interventions but observed trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The MONICA Project was a WHO observational study aimed at monitoring global trends and risk factors in cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains methotrexate’s primary mechanism of action as a disease-modifying agent in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of AICAR transformylase

 

  • In rheumatoid arthritis, methotrexate’s anti-inflammatory effect is primarily due to inhibition of the enzyme AICAR transformylase.
  • This leads to accumulation of AICAR, which inhibits adenosine deaminase, resulting in increased extracellular adenosine.
  • Adenosine has potent anti-inflammatory effects, such as reducing neutrophil adhesion, suppressing cytokine release, and downregulating T-cell activity — key in RA symptom relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase: This is methotrexate’s anticancer mechanism, leading to reduced DNA synthesis. Although it contributes to its immunosuppressive action at higher doses, it is not the most important mechanism in RA at low-dose therapy.

 

Option B. Inhibition of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase: This is the mechanism of leflunomide, another DMARD, not methotrexate. It inhibits pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Suppression of B-cell differentiation: This is not the primary mechanism of methotrexate. Rituximab, a monoclonal antibody against CD20, suppresses B-cell function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methotrexate acts in rheumatoid arthritis primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to adenosine accumulation and anti-inflammatory effects distinct from its antifolate anticancer mechanism.

choices.text: Meckel’s diverticulum is the most common lead point in idiopathic cases of intussusception.
Red currant jelly stools are typically observed during the early asymptomatic phase.
Hydrostatic reduction success is confirmed by the reflux of contrast material into the stomach.
The recurrence rate is higher after hydrostatic reduction than after operative reduction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intussusception is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The recurrence rate is higher after hydrostatic reduction than after operative reduction

 

The recurrence rate after hydrostatic reduction (5–10%) is indeed higher than that after operative reduction (1–4%).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel’s diverticulum is the most common lead point in idiopathic cases of intussusception: Incorrect. Meckel’s diverticulum is the most common pathologic lead point, not seen in idiopathic cases. Idiopathic intussusception has no clear etiology and is often associated with hypertrophied Peyer’s patches.

 

Option B. Red currant jelly stools are typically observed during the early asymptomatic phase: Incorrect. Red currant jelly stools occur later in the disease and not during the asymptomatic phase.

 

Option C. Hydrostatic reduction success is confirmed by the reflux of contrast material into the stomach: Incorrect. Successful reduction via hydrostatic (air or contrast) enema is confirmed by reflux of air or barium into the small bowel, not the stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intussusception commonly presents in infants aged 3–36 months with episodic abdominal pain and red currant jelly stools. 
  • It is managed primarily by hydrostatic or pneumatic reduction, but recurrence is more common after non-operative reduction.

choices.text: Sensitivity and specificity have improved due to lower disease burden

questions.text: Following the successful implementation of a disease control program, the prevalence of a particular infectious disease in the community has decreased by 90%. A physician continues using the same diagnostic test to identify the disease. Which of the following best describes how the test's performance is now affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negative predictive value has increased

 

  • When disease prevalence decreases, the negative predictive value (NPV) of a diagnostic test increases. 
  • This means the probability that a negative test result truly rules out the disease becomes higher. Predictive values are directly influenced by disease prevalence:
  • As prevalence drops:
    → Positive Predictive Value (PPV)decreases
    → Negative Predictive Value (NPV)increases
  • The test’s sensitivity and specificity, however, are intrinsic properties of the test and remain unchanged regardless of disease prevalence.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Test specificity has increased: Incorrect. Specificity is an inherent property of the test and remains constant, regardless of disease prevalence.

 

Option B. Positive predictive value has increased: Incorrect. In fact, as prevalence decreases, PPV decreases because false positives make up a larger proportion of the positive results.

 

Option D. Sensitivity and specificity have improved due to lower disease burden: Incorrect. Sensitivity and specificity are fixed characteristics of the test and do not vary with disease prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When disease prevalence decreases, the negative predictive value of a diagnostic test increases, making negative results more reliable.

choices.text: c-ANCA positivity and rapidly progressive renal failure
Elevated serum IgE and bronchial hyperresponsiveness
Increased Ga-67 uptake in the lacrimal and salivary glands
Caseating necrosis and acid-fast bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen staining

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, nasal crusting, occasional epistaxis, and progressive anosmia. She also reports chronic dry cough and unintentional weight loss of 4 kg. On physical examination, she has bilateral, non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and inspection of the nasal cavity reveals mucosal crusting with erythematous patches over the nasal tip. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and patchy interstitial infiltrates. CT of the head and neck shows mucosal thickening of multiple paranasal sinuses, septal perforation, and mild saddle-nose deformity. ACE levels are elevated. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased Ga-67 uptake in the lacrimal and salivary glands

 

This patient presents with systemic sarcoidosis involving both the upper and lower respiratory tracts, suggested by anosmia, nasal crusting, saddle-nose deformity (from septal perforation), non-productive cough, and hilar lymphadenopathy. 

 

The Ga-67 scan in sarcoidosis characteristically shows increased uptake in the lacrimal, parotid, and nasopharyngeal glands, forming the classic “panda sign.” This occurs due to granulomatous infiltration of these glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. c-ANCA positivity and rapidly progressive renal failure: Seen in Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), which is also associated with septal perforation and URT symptoms. However, GPA shows necrotizing granulomas, c-ANCA positivity, and often leads to glomerulonephritis, none of which are features here.

 

Option B. Elevated serum IgE and bronchial hyperresponsiveness: Suggestive of Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA). ABPA is associated with asthma, bronchiectasis, and high IgE—not with nasal crusting, uveitis, or granulomas.

 

Option D. Caseating necrosis and acid-fast bacilli on Ziehl-Neelsen staining: Seen in tuberculosis, which must be ruled out in granulomatous diseases. However, non-caseating granulomas and absence of AFB point away from TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Upper respiratory tract involvement includes nasal obstruction, anosmia, septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity. A hallmark radiologic finding is the “panda sign” on Ga-67 scan, indicating salivary and lacrimal gland involvement.

questions.text: A 39-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation presents to the labor ward with painful uterine contractions and minimal vaginal bleeding mixed with mucus. On examination, her cervix is beginning to efface and dilate. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bloody show

 

  • A bloody show occurs when the cervix begins to efface and dilate in preparation for labor. 
  • This leads to the release of the mucus plug, which has sealed the cervix during pregnancy.
  • Small blood vessels in the cervix rupture, causing minimal vaginal bleeding mixed with mucus, which is a normal finding in early labor. 
  • The presence of painful uterine contractions further supports the diagnosis of bloody show.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding, not associated with contractions or mucus.

 

Option B. Placental abruption: Causes painful uterine contractions but is associated with significant vaginal bleeding, not just a mucus-tinged bloody show.

 

Option D. Vasa previa: Involves fetal blood vessels crossing the cervical os, leading to painless vaginal bleeding. This condition can cause fetal distress and is not associated with the mucus seen in a bloody show.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A bloody show is a normal finding at the onset of labor and occurs when the cervix effaces and dilates, releasing the mucus plug mixed with small amounts of blood. It is different from the heavy vaginal bleeding seen in placenta previa or placental abruption.
