Transmitted via ingestion of cysts; infective form is trophozoite
Transmitted by fecal contamination from reduvid bug; infective form is metacyclic trypomastigote
Transmitted by tick bite; infective form is sporozoite

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from a rural village in South America presents with fever, swelling around the eye (Romaña sign), and malaise. He recalls waking up with an insect bite on his face. Examination and blood smear suggest infection with a protozoan parasite. Which of the following statements best describes the transmission and infective form of the organism responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transmitted by fecal contamination from reduvid bug; infective form is metacyclic trypomastigote

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is transmitted by Triatomine (Reduvid) bugs, also known as "kissing bugs."
  • Transmission occurs when the infected feces of the bug contaminate the bite site or mucous membranes—usually through rubbing or scratching.
  • The infective form is the metacyclic trypomastigote, which enters the bloodstream and invades host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted via mosquito bite; infective form is promastigote: Incorrect. This describes Leishmania spp., not T. cruzi. Leishmania is transmitted by sandflies, not mosquitoes, and its infective form is promastigote.

 

Option B. Transmitted via ingestion of cysts; infective form is trophozoite: Incorrect. This fits Entamoeba histolytica, transmitted via ingested cysts, not via insect vectors. The trophozoite is the pathogenic form, not the infective one.

 

Option D. Transmitted by tick bite; infective form is sporozoite: Incorrect. This applies to Babesia (via ticks) or Plasmodium (via mosquitoes), both using sporozoites as the infective form—not relevant to T. cruzi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi is transmitted via fecal contamination from the reduviid bug, and the infective form is the metacyclic trypomastigote.

choices.text: Inhibits glucagon secretion by an incretin mimetic
Increases insulin release from beta cells
Inhibits reabsorption of glucose in the kidney

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with a low-grade fever and increased urinary frequency for 2 days. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and started a new diabetes medication 2 months ago. He also reports hypogastric abdominal pain.

 

Investigations:

 

Urine dipstick:

 

  • Nitrites: Positive
  • Leucocytes: Positive

 

What is the drug’s mechanism of action that has likely caused his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibits reabsorption of glucose in the kidney

 

The patient’s symptoms are highly suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI):

 

  • Low-grade fever
  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Hypogastric abdominal pain (suggestive of cystitis or lower UTI)
  • Urine dipstick: Positive for nitrites and leukocytes (indicative of UTI, with nitrites indicating the presence of gram-negative bacteria, commonly E. coli).

 

The likely cause is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor such as empagliflozin, dapagliflozin, or canagliflozin, which was started 2 months ago for type 2 diabetes mellitus.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inhibition of alpha-glucosidase (e.g., Acarbose): Causes gastrointestinal side effects (e.g., flatulence, diarrhoea), not UTIs. Works by delaying carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, not in the kidneys.

 

Option B. Inhibits glucagon secretion by an incretin mimetic (GLP-1 receptor agonists - e.g., Liraglutide, Exenatide): Can cause nausea, vomiting, and pancreatitis, but not UTIs. Works by increasing insulin and suppressing glucagon, not by causing glycosuria.

 

Option C. Increases insulin release from beta cells (Sulfonylureas - e.g., Gliclazide): Increases the risk of hypoglycemia, not UTIs. Works by stimulating pancreatic beta cells, not the renal tubules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors cause glucosuria, leading to:
    • Increased UTI risk
    • Increased risk of genital mycotic infections
  • First-line investigation for UTI: Urine dipstick (leukocytes and nitrites)
  • Most common UTI pathogen: E. coli

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for evaluation after experiencing a second-trimester pregnancy loss. She reports a history of painless cervical dilation leading to pregnancy loss at 20 weeks in her previous pregnancy. On further questioning, she mentions undergoing multiple gynecologic procedures in the past. Which of the following is not a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometrial biopsy

 

  • Cervical insufficiency (also known as cervical incompetence) is defined as the inability of the cervix to maintain pregnancy in the absence of uterine contractions or labor, often leading to painless second-trimester pregnancy loss. 
  • Various surgical and mechanical factors can weaken the cervix and predispose to this condition.
  • Endometrial biopsy involves sampling the uterine lining (endometrium) without affecting the cervical structure or tensile strength. Since this procedure does not disrupt or remove cervical tissue, it is not a risk factor for cervical insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, often performed for treating or diagnosing precancerous cervical lesions. The excision of cervical tissue weakens its structural integrity, making it a significant risk factor for cervical insufficiency.

 

Option B. Dilatation and curettage (D&C): Repeated D&C procedures may cause trauma to the cervix due to excessive dilation, leading to cervical incompetence. The weakening of cervical tissue from multiple interventions is a recognized cause of recurrent pregnancy loss.

 

Option D. Trachelectomy: Trachelectomy involves partial or complete removal of the cervix, significantly increasing the risk of cervical insufficiency. It is often performed in patients with early-stage cervical cancer but results in weakened cervical support, making pregnancy retention difficult.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical insufficiency is associated with procedures that damage or remove portions of the cervix, such as conization, dilatation and curettage (D&C), and trachelectomy. However, an endometrial biopsy does not compromise cervical strength and is not a risk factor for cervical insufficiency.

choices.text: Dose of radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of its distance from the source
Small vessels are resistant to radiation
Normal tissues recover better from fractionated doses
Actively dividing mucosa is highly radiosensitive

questions.text: A female patient with a confirmed diagnosis of stage 2B cervical cancer is undergoing a course of radiotherapy as part of her treatment plan. In planning and delivering this therapy, which of the following principles is most important to maximize therapeutic benefit while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissues?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dose of radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of its distance from the source

 

  • The inverse square law is fundamental in radiotherapy, stating that radiation intensity falls off proportionally to the square of the distance from the source. 
  • This principle is especially critical in brachytherapy, often used in cervical cancer, where a radioactive source is placed close to the tumor. 
  • It ensures that the tumor receives a high dose, while nearby structures like the rectum and bladder receive a much lower dose, thereby minimizing toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small vessels are resistant to radiation: Incorrect. Small blood vessels are actually sensitive to radiation. Damage to vasculature contributes to fibrosis, ischemia, and tissue necrosis.

 

Option C. Normal tissues recover better from fractionated doses: While true, this is a general principle of radiotherapy but not as directly relevant to dose distribution and spatial protection of normal tissues as the inverse square law.

 

Option D. Actively dividing mucosa is highly radiosensitive: This is also true, but it highlights a side effect risk rather than a principle used to optimize treatment delivery. The question asks about planning to minimize damage, making this less directly relevant than the inverse square law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In radiotherapy, the inverse square law ensures precise dose delivery by stating that radiation intensity decreases with the square of the distance, enabling effective tumor treatment while sparing nearby tissues.

choices.text: Positive pressure ventilation with bag and mask

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Step A in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Consider CPAP

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, Step A is initiated when the baby has apnea, gasping, or heart rate <100 bpm. The recommended interventions in Step A include:
    • Positive Pressure Ventilation (PPV) using a bag and mask
    • SpO₂ monitoring to guide oxygen supplementation
    • ECG monitor placement for accurate heart rate measurement
  • CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) is not indicated in apneic or gasping babies or those with bradycardia. Instead, CPAP is considered in babies who are breathing spontaneously but have labored breathing or persistent central cyanosis, which occurs in a different clinical context and not during Step A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with bag and mask: Correct step — Initiated when HR <100 bpm or apnea/gasping is present.

 

Option C. SpO₂ monitoring: Correct — Used to monitor oxygenation and guide oxygen delivery during resuscitation.

 

Option D. Consider ECG monitor: Correct — Helps in rapid and accurate heart rate assessment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Step A in neonatal resuscitation involves initiating PPV, monitoring oxygenation, and assessing heart rate using ECG. 
  • CPAP is not a part of Step A; it is reserved for neonates who are breathing but have labored respirations or persistent cyanosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with chronic stable angina and reduced ejection fraction heart failure is prescribed a new medication that lowers heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility or blood pressure. It selectively inhibits the funny sodium (If) current in the sinoatrial node, thereby slowing depolarization. Which of the following drugs has the described mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivabradine

 

  • Ivabradine selectively inhibits the funny current (If) in the sinoatrial node, which is responsible for phase 4 depolarization.
  • By slowing this current, it reduces heart rate without affecting contractility (inotropy) or blood pressure.
  • It is used in:
    • Chronic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction in patients who are in sinus rhythm and have a resting HR ≥70 bpm
    • Chronic stable angina in patients intolerant to or inadequately controlled on beta blockers

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: A beta-1 selective blocker that reduces HR and contractility; also lowers BP. Not selective for the funny current.

 

Option B. Verapamil: A non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that reduces HR, contractility, and BP. Works via calcium channels, not the funny current.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Inhibits Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase, increases intracellular calcium, and enhances contractility; it also increases vagal tone, reducing HR, but does not target the funny current.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ivabradine lowers heart rate by selectively inhibiting the funny sodium (If) current in the SA node without affecting myocardial contractility or blood pressure. It is used in chronic heart failure and stable angina.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with progressive developmental regression, hypotonia, absent deep tendon reflexes, muscle wasting, irritability, and visual impairment with optic atrophy. Neurologic examination reveals a combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs, nystagmus, and myoclonic jerks. MRI shows white matter demyelination. Urinary sulfatides are elevated. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arylsulfatase A

 

  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. 
  • This leads to accumulation of cerebroside sulfate in central and peripheral nervous system tissues, resulting in demyelination. 
  • Clinically, it manifests with motor regression, hypotonia, absent DTRs, optic atrophy, seizures (including myoclonic), and combined UMN/LMN signs. Elevated urinary sulfatides support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactocerebrosidase: Deficiency causes Krabbe disease, not MLD. Krabbe presents with similar symptoms but is due to psychosine accumulation, not sulfatide.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Deficiency leads to Tay-Sachs disease, which presents with a cherry-red spot on macula, hyperacusis, and developmental regression but without sulfatide accumulation.

 

Option D. β-glucocerebrosidase: Deficiency causes Gaucher disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, and anemia—not typically associated with leukodystrophy or sulfatide accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy is caused by arylsulfatase A deficiency, resulting in sulfatide accumulation and progressive demyelination in the central and peripheral nervous systems. 
  • Clinical features include motor regression, hypotonia, visual loss, seizures, and combined UMN and LMN signs.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to a community clinic with low-grade fever and generalized lymphadenopathy. She mentions frequent contact with stray cats. Serological testing is ordered to confirm the diagnosis. The lab performs a Sabin-Feldman dye test as part of the evaluation. This diagnostic test is used for identifying which of the following parasitic infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a highly specific serological test used to detect antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, the causative agent of toxoplasmosis.
  • This test measures the ability of patient serum to alter the permeability of the parasite's cell membrane, which prevents uptake of a blue dye (methylene blue).
  • It is considered a reference standard for detecting Toxoplasma antibodies, especially in congenital infections and systemic disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria is diagnosed by peripheral blood smear and rapid antigen tests, not by the Sabin-Feldman dye test. Antibody detection is not typically useful for acute diagnosis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis: Diagnosed via tissue smears, culture, or PCR, and in some cases Montenegro skin test or rK39 antigen tests—not by Sabin-Feldman dye test.

 

Option D. Giardiasis: Diagnosed by stool microscopy, antigen detection, or NAAT (PCR). The Sabin-Feldman dye test plays no role in giardiasis diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a specific serological test used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis by detecting antibodies to Toxoplasma gondii.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with primary open-angle glaucoma is started on topical therapy to lower intraocular pressure. She has a documented sulfonamide allergy that previously resulted in rash and angioedema. Which of the following medications should be avoided due to risk of cross-reactivity with sulfonamides?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brinzolamide

 

  • Brinzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, structurally related to sulfonamides.
  • Although administered locally in the eye, systemic absorption can occur, and cross-reactivity in sulfa-allergic patients has been reported.
  • Therefore, it is contraindicated or used with caution in patients with sulfonamide hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levobunolol: A non-selective beta-blocker used topically for glaucoma. It is not a sulfonamide derivative.

 

Option B. Bimatoprost: A prostaglandin analog that increases uveoscleral outflow. It does not contain a sulfa structure.

 

Option D. Brimonidine: An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that decreases aqueous humor production. It has no sulfonamide component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brinzolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in glaucoma, should be avoided in patients with sulfonamide allergy due to potential cross-reactivity.

choices.text: Hydrolysis of ATP in the myosin
Removal of Ca²⁺ from troponin C
Attachment of ATP to the myosin head
Active pumping of Ca²⁺ into the cisternae

questions.text: Relaxation of muscle occurs by involving all of the following mechanisms except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrolysis of ATP in the myosin

 

  • Muscle relaxation is the process that occurs when the contraction ceases, allowing the muscle fibers to return to their resting state. 
  • ATP hydrolysis by myosin ATPase provides the energy required for the power stroke during contraction.
  • This step is essential for muscle contraction, not relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Removal of Ca²⁺ from troponin C:

 

  • During contraction, calcium ions (Ca²⁺) bind to troponin C, leading to a conformational change that shifts tropomyosin, exposing the myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • For relaxation to occur, Ca²⁺ must be removed from troponin C, allowing tropomyosin to block the binding sites, preventing further cross-bridge cycling.

 

Option C. Attachment of ATP to the Myosin Head:

 

  • After a power stroke, ATP binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from actin, breaking the cross-bridge.
  • Without ATP binding, the muscle would remain in a contracted state, leading to rigor mortis.

 

Option D. Active Pumping of Ca²⁺ into the Cisternae:

 

  • Sarcoplasmic Reticulum Ca²⁺ ATPase (SERCA) actively transports Ca²⁺ back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) using ATP.
  • This reduces intracellular Ca²⁺ concentration, promoting muscle relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Muscle relaxation requires removal of Ca²⁺ from troponin C, binding of ATP to myosin for detachment, and active transport of Ca²⁺ back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. 
  • ATP hydrolysis by myosin ATPase is essential for contraction, not relaxation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with nocturia, urinary urgency, and decreased urinary stream. Digital rectal examination reveals a smoothly enlarged prostate. He is diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). His symptoms are moderate and impact his daily routine, especially sleep. Which of the following pharmacologic agents is most appropriate for initial symptomatic management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tamsulosin

 

  • Tamsulosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker that relaxes smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow and relieving irritative urinary symptoms.
  • It provides rapid relief of symptoms and is considered first-line pharmacologic therapy for moderate BPH symptoms.
  • Unlike 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, alpha-blockers do not shrink the prostate but are very effective in early symptom control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Finasteride: A 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that shrinks prostate size by reducing dihydrotestosterone (DHT) levels. However, it takes months to show effect and is not preferred for initial symptom relief.

 

Option C. Oxybutynin: An anticholinergic agent used for overactive bladder and urge incontinence, but it is not first-line for BPH. It can worsen urinary retention in patients with obstructive symptoms.

 

Option D. Desmopressin: A vasopressin analog used in nocturnal enuresis and central diabetes insipidus, but it has no role in BPH management and can cause hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tamsulosin, an alpha-1 blocker, is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia due to its ability to relax prostatic smooth muscle and relieve urinary obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is this instrument most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

 

The instrument shown is a Kerrison bone punch, a specialized surgical tool designed for precise removal of thin bone plates. It is most commonly used in Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) — a procedure performed to treat nasolacrimal duct obstruction by creating a direct communication between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity.

 

In DCR, the Kerrison punch is used to remove parts of the lacrimal bone and frontal process of the maxilla, which are essential steps in exposing the lacrimal sac and forming the bony ostium for drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital decompression: Performed to relieve orbital pressure in conditions like thyroid eye disease, it involves removal of orbital walls using high-speed burrs or chisels, not a Kerrison punch, which is not designed for extensive bone removal in deep orbital spaces.

 

Option B. Probing and irrigation: This procedure is done primarily in infants with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction and uses Bowman’s probes and lacrimal cannulae. It does not involve bone removal, so the Kerrison punch is not applicable.

 

Option D. Enucleation: This is the surgical removal of the entire globe (eyeball), often for intraocular malignancy or trauma. The procedure involves optic nerve scissors, muscle hooks, and snares, and does not require bone removal; therefore, a Kerrison punch is not used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kerrison bone punch is commonly used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) to remove portions of the lacrimal bone and frontal process of the maxilla, facilitating the creation of a bony ostium between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity.

choices.text: Nuchal translucency measurement and serum PAPP-A & free beta-hCG

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 12 weeks of gestation visits the antenatal clinic for routine prenatal care. She has no significant past medical history but is concerned about the risk of Down syndrome as her sister has a child with the condition. The patient is advised about first-trimester screening options for Down syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test at this gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nuchal translucency measurement and serum PAPP-A & free beta-hCG

 

  • The first-trimester screening for Down syndrome is performed between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation and consists of:
  • Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement via ultrasound
  • Maternal serum screening for pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) and free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG)
  • This combination helps assess the risk of fetal aneuploidy, including trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18, and trisomy 13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quadruple test: This test is done between 15-18 weeks of gestation, making it inappropriate at 12 weeks. It includes AFP, β-hCG, estriol, and inhibin A.

 

Option C. Amniocentesis: A diagnostic test performed after 15 weeks, used if screening tests indicate high risk. It carries a small risk of fetal loss.

 

Option D. Cell-free fetal DNA testing: A highly sensitive non-invasive test for fetal aneuploidy. It is usually done from 10 weeks onward but is recommended primarily for high-risk pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • First-trimester screening for Down syndrome includes nuchal translucency measurement, PAPP-A, and free β-hCG, ideally performed between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation. 
  • The Quadruple test is a second-trimester screening performed between 15 and 18 weeks.

questions.text: A decrease in blood pressure is detected by _______________ in the common carotid arteries and leads to a _______________ reflex that stimulates an increase in the heart rate and force of contraction.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoreceptor; sympathetic

 

  • A decrease in blood pressure is detected by Chemoreceptors located in the carotid sinus (at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery) and the aortic arch. 
  • These receptors are stretch-sensitive mechanoreceptors that monitor changes in arterial wall tension.

 

When blood pressure falls:

 

  • There is reduced stretch on the baroreceptors.
  • This leads to decreased firing of afferent impulses via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) from the carotid sinus to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla.
    • If the BP falls below 60 mmHg Chemoreceptors will be activated, leading to activation of Vasomotor Centre (Increasing sympathetic outflow) and inhibiting Cardio- Vagal centre (Decreasing parasympathetic (vagal) tone)

 

Sympathetic reflex effects include:

 

  • Increased heart rate (positive chronotropy)
  • Increased force of contraction (positive inotropy)
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction (↑ systemic vascular resistance)

 

Chemoreceptors sense low BP and trigger a compensatory sympathetic reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baroreceptors; parasympathetic: Incorrect. Parasympathetic output decreases, not increases, in response to low BP.

 

Option C. Nociceptors; parasympathetic: Incorrect. Nociceptors detect pain, not blood pressure.

 

Option D. Nociceptors; sympathetic: Incorrect. Again, nociceptors are unrelated to baroreflex control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect changes in blood pressure. 
  • A drop in blood pressure leads to decreased baroreceptor firing, triggering a sympathetic reflex that increases heart rate and contractility to restore blood pressure.

questions.text: A reproductive health researcher is evaluating the performance of a new contraceptive method by tracking the number of failures occurring in each individual month of use over time. Which of the following statistical tools is most appropriate for analyzing this type of month-by-month failure data?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Life table method

 

  • The life table method is the correct analytical tool to calculate the failure rate of a contraceptive for each month of use. 
  • It is designed for time-to-event (survival) analysis, where the focus is on how long individuals remain event-free—in this case, pregnancy-free—while using a contraceptive.
  • This method accounts for varying durations of exposure, loss to follow-up, and allows for interval-specific failure rates to be calculated, such as monthly or yearly risk. 
  • It provides a dynamic and detailed view of contraceptive effectiveness over time, which is more accurate than methods that simply average rates over a total period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Couple protection rate: This measures the proportion of eligible couples effectively protected against pregnancy by any method of contraception at a given time. It is a coverage indicator, not a method to calculate failure rate per month of use.

 

Option C. Gross fertility rate: This is a demographic indicator that estimates the number of births per 1,000 women of reproductive age in a year. It is unrelated to contraceptive failure or month-specific risk.

 

Option D. Pearl Index: Though commonly used to express contraceptive failure rates, it calculates the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure. It does not assess failure by individual months, and it is less precise when follow-up durations vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The life table method is used to calculate the failure rate of a contraceptive method for each individual month of use, offering interval-specific accuracy over time.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with right upper quadrant discomfort and a history of consuming raw aquatic vegetation while traveling through rural South Asia. His liver enzymes are mildly elevated. A stool ova and parasite exam reveals operculated eggs. Which of the following trematodes is most likely responsible for his condition, considering aquatic plants act as a second intermediate host in its life cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fasciola hepatica

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, also known as the sheep liver fluke, is a trematode that infects the hepatobiliary system.
  • Its life cycle involves:
    1. Freshwater snails as the first intermediate host.
    2. Aquatic plants (e.g., watercress) as the second intermediate host.
  • Humans become infected by ingesting metacercaria encysted on contaminated aquatic vegetation.
  • This is a hallmark feature that clearly distinguishes Fasciola hepatica from other trematodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schistosoma: Schistosomes have only one intermediate host—freshwater snails. Humans are infected by direct skin penetration of cercariae. Aquatic plants are not involved.

 

Option C. Clonorchis sinensis: This liver fluke also uses snails as the first intermediate host, but its second intermediate host is freshwater fish, not aquatic plants.

 

Option D. Paragonimus: Known as the lung fluke, it uses crustaceans (e.g., crabs or crayfish) as its second intermediate host, not aquatic plants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica is a trematode that uses aquatic plants as its second intermediate host. Ingestion of metacercariae from contaminated vegetation leads to hepatic infection in humans.Top of Form

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents with fatigue, difficulty concentrating in school, and tingling sensations in his hands and feet. His parents mention he has become more forgetful and irritable over the past few weeks. He has also been following a strict diet and taking unregulated dietary supplements. Physical examination reveals diminished sensation in a stocking-glove distribution. His random blood glucose is elevated. Which of the following trace element deficiencies is the most likely contributor to his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chromium

 

  • Chromium plays an essential role in potentiating insulin action and facilitating normal glucose metabolism. 
  • Deficiency is rare but can occur in children with restrictive diets or chronic illnesses like diabetes. 
  • Clinical manifestations include impaired glucose tolerance, peripheral neuropathy, and encephalopathy—as seen in this child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency may result in anemia, neutropenia, and bone abnormalities but not typically glucose issues.

 

Option C. Selenium: Linked to cardiomyopathy and hypothyroidism but not glucose regulation.

 

Option D. Zinc: Important for growth and immunity, but deficiency does not impair glucose tolerance or cause neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In children with diabetes or restrictive diets, chromium deficiency may present with worsening glycemic control, neuropathy, and neurological changes due to its role in enhancing insulin function.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding chest trauma are true? 

 

  1. ECG should be performed in all cases with associated sternal fracture
  2. Underwater seal drainage is indicated if pneumothorax is present
  3. Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration
  4. Urgent surgery is required in all cases of massive hemothorax
  5. Sternal fractures are markers of possible associated internal injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B, C, E

 

A. True: ECG should be performed in all cases with associated sternal fracture: Sternal fractures can be associated with blunt cardiac injuries. ECG is the first diagnostic tool used to assess myocardial involvement.

 

B. True: Underwater seal drainage is indicated if pneumothorax is present: In cases of pneumothorax secondary to chest trauma, intercostal drainage with an underwater seal is the standard initial management.

 

C. True: Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration: Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration, as X ray or CT may miss the rupture.

 

E. True: Sternal fractures are markers of possible associated internal injuries: Sternal fractures should raise suspicion for other potentially life-threatening injuries such as myocardial rupture or thoracic aortic injury.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

D. False: Urgent surgery is required in all cases of massive hemothorax: Urgent surgery is not required in all massive hemothorax cases. Indications include blood output of 1500 cc instantly or > 250 ml/hour for 3 consecutive hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chest trauma evaluation begins with clinical assessment, followed by imaging such as chest X-ray. 
  • ECG is essential in suspected cardiac involvement, especially with sternal fractures. 
  • Not all cases require surgical intervention; conservative management is often sufficient depending on associated injuries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with an episode of transient ischemic attack. Imaging studies reveal a vascular abnormality in the Circle of Willis. Identify the correctly labelled structures in the given image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) (A). Anterior communicating artery, (B). ICA, (C). Infundibulum, (D). Posterior communicating artery, (E). III nerve, (F). IV nerve

 

The Circle of Willis is an anastomotic arterial system located at the base of the brain. The labeled parts in the image correspond to:

 

  1. Anterior communicating artery: A short artery connecting the two anterior cerebral arteries.
  2. Internal carotid artery - ICA: The terminal branch of the internal carotid artery, contributing to the Circle of Willis.
  3. Infundibulum: The pituitary stalk, part of the hypothalamus.
  4. Posterior communicating artery: Connects the ICA to the posterior cerebral artery.
  5. III nerve - Oculomotor nerve: Emerges from the interpeduncular fossa, visible near the Circle of Willis.
  6. IV nerve - Trochlear nerve: Arises from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Circle of Willis consists of the anterior communicating artery, internal carotid artery, and posterior communicating artery, along with other contributing vessels. Cranial nerves III and IV are in close proximity to this structure.

questions.text: A 66-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of osteoporosis presents for a follow-up evaluation. Despite adherence to calcium and vitamin D supplementation, her recent DEXA scan shows progressive bone loss. She is started on a medication known for having a dual mechanism. It reduces both bone resorption and stimulates bone formation. Which of the following drugs most likely has this combined pharmacologic profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strontium ranelate

 

  • Strontium ranelate is unique among osteoporosis medications in that it exhibits a dual mechanism of action:
    • It decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast differentiation and activity.
    • Simultaneously, it increases bone formation by stimulating osteoblast replication and function.
  • This dual effect makes it highly effective in managing postmenopausal osteoporosis and reducing fracture risk.
  • Although effective, it has limited use globally due to cardiovascular risk concerns, especially in patients with pre-existing heart disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Zoledronic acid: A bisphosphonate that works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. It does not stimulate bone formation, and thus does not have dual action like strontium ranelate.

 

Option B. Denosumab: A monoclonal antibody that binds RANKL, thereby inhibiting osteoclast formation and activity. It reduces bone resorption but does not promote bone formation.

 

Option D. Teriparatide: A recombinant parathyroid hormone (PTH 1-34) analog that stimulates osteoblastic activity and promotes bone formation. However, it may also lead to increased bone resorption if used long-term and does not simultaneously reduce resorption, unlike strontium ranelate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strontium ranelate is the only osteoporosis drug that both decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation, making it pharmacologically distinct among anti-osteoporotic therapies.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; T-cell mediated injury to the podocytes
Berger’s disease; Deposition of IgA in the mesangium

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady is evaluated for worsening periorbital swelling and leg edema over the past week. Physical examination shows bilateral lower extremity pitting edema and facial puffiness. Urinalysis reveals 4+ proteinuria. Blood tests show hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and normal renal function. A renal biopsy is performed, and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and associated pathogenic mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy; Autoantibodies against the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor

 

  • This child presents with classic nephrotic syndrome:
    • 4+ proteinuria
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Edema
  • The biopsy image shows diffuse capillary wall thickening without hypercellularity, best appreciated on silver stain. This is characteristic of membranous nephropathy.
  • The most common cause of primary membranous nephropathy is the formation of autoantibodies against the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) found on podocyte surfaces. 
  • These immune complexes deposit in the subepithelial space, resulting in complement activation, podocyte injury, and loss of filtration barrier, causing massive proteinuria.
  • Though classically seen in adults, membranous nephropathy can also occur in children, especially when other features (like diffuse basement membrane thickening) support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; T-cell mediated injury to the podocytes:

 

  • This condition causes segmental glomerular sclerosis, not diffuse capillary wall thickening.
  • The image and uniform membrane changes are not consistent with segmental sclerosis.
  • FSGS is more common in African American children and associated with podocyte effacement, not PLA2R antibodies.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative nephropathy; C3 nephritic factor auto-antibodies: 

 

  • Usually presents as a mixed nephritic-nephrotic syndrome, often with low complement levels.
  • The hallmark feature is "tram-track" appearance on silver stain due to GBM splitting, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Berger’s disease; Deposition of IgA in the mesangium:
 

  • IgA nephropathy typically presents with episodic gross hematuria, not pure nephrotic syndrome.
  • Biopsy would show mesangial expansion and IgA deposition, not uniform capillary wall thickening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous nephropathy is characterized by subepithelial immune complex deposition due to autoantibodies against the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor, leading to diffuse basement membrane thickening and nephrotic syndrome.

Match the following health committees in India with their respective recommendations related to healthcare delivery: 

 

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A–4, B–3, C–1, D–2

 

A. Kartar Singh Committee → 4: Recommended multipurpose health worker scheme for PHC-level restructuring and better workforce utilization.

 

B. Chadah Committee → 3: Proposed integration of malaria surveillance into general health services using basic health workers.

 

C. Srivastava Committee → 1: Known for introducing the three-tier rural healthcare system (SC, PHC, CHC) and a strong referral-based structure.

 

D. Mudaliar Committee → 2: Recommended improvement of district hospitals and higher-level facilities, not structural changes at the grassroots level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different health committees in India have contributed distinct recommendations.
  • The Srivastava Committee established the three-tier rural health system, while others focused on disease control, infrastructure, and workforce restructuring.

choices.text: A new act of negligence by the original defendant, resulting in the immediate liability for damages.
A new act or event that breaks the chain of causation between the defendant's original act and the injury sustained by the claimant, potentially absolving the defendant from liability.
A medical condition that was pre-existing and unrelated to the defendant's actions, therefore preventing liability.
An act of contributory negligence by the claimant, which leads to a complete bar on claiming damages.

questions.text: In the context of medical negligence, the legal principle of Novus Actus Interveniens refers to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A new act or event that breaks the chain of causation between the defendant's original act and the injury sustained by the claimant, potentially absolving the defendant from liability.

 

In the context of medical negligence, the legal doctrine of Novus Actus Interveniens applies when a new act or event occurs after the original negligent act, which is sufficiently independent and unforeseeable, and it breaks the chain of causation between the defendant's act and the claimant's injury. This principle can absolve the original defendant of legal liability if the intervening act is considered the real cause of the injury.

 

For example, if a doctor commits a negligent act, but the patient’s injury is primarily caused by an unrelated and unforeseen event afterward (e.g., improper handling by another third party or patient’s own unexpected actions), the original doctor may no longer be legally liable, as the new act is seen as the intervening cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A new act of negligence by the original defendant, resulting in the immediate liability for damages: Incorrect. This choice refers to a continuation of negligence by the same defendant, which does not break the chain of causation. In fact, it reinforces liability, rather than potentially removing it.

 

Option C. A medical condition that was pre-existing and unrelated to the defendant's actions, therefore preventing liability: Incorrect. While pre-existing conditions may influence damages or causation, they do not qualify as a novus actus interveniens, because they are not new acts or events, and they do not intervene between the defendant’s act and the injury.

 

Option D. An act of contributory negligence by the claimant, which leads to a complete bar on claiming damages: Incorrect. Contributory negligence refers to fault on the part of the claimant, not an intervening act by a third party. It may reduce or bar damages, but it is a different legal principle from Novus Actus Interveniens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In medical negligence, Novus Actus Interveniens refers to a new act or event that breaks the chain of causation between the defendant’s original act and the claimant’s injury, potentially absolving the defendant from liability.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida at 31 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of lower abdominal pain and occasional tightening of the uterus. She has no history of trauma or recent intercourse. Which of the following is the most definitive way to confirm preterm labor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Digital cervical examination

 

  • Preterm labor is diagnosed when a pregnant woman at less than 37 weeks gestation presents with regular uterine contractions accompanied by cervical changes (dilatation ≥3 cm or significant effacement). 
  • The gold standard for confirming preterm labor is digital cervical examination, which assesses cervical dilatation and effacement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound for cervical length measurement: A short cervix (<2.5 cm) is a risk factor for preterm labor but does not confirm active labor. It is used as a screening tool, not for diagnosis.

 

Option B. Fetal fibronectin assay: A positive fetal fibronectin test indicates a risk for preterm birth but does not confirm active labor. A negative test is useful for ruling out preterm labor in asymptomatic women but does not replace cervical examination.

 

Option C. External tocodynamometry: Measures uterine contractions but does not confirm preterm labor unless accompanied by cervical changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preterm labor is confirmed by cervical dilatation and effacement assessed via digital cervical examination, along with regular uterine contractions. 
  • Other tests (e.g., fetal fibronectin, cervical length) assess risk but do not confirm active labor.

questions.text: A hospital administrator is overseeing the construction of a new maternal health wing. An arrow diagram is created to represent the logical sequence of tasks, ensuring that events occur in the right order and that the project remains on schedule. This diagram also helps improve communication across departments and allows for the generation of timely progress updates. What is this project management tool called?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

 

  • PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) is a project management tool that uses an arrow diagram to map out the logical sequence of events necessary for completing a project. 
  • It is particularly helpful in:
    • Planning, scheduling, and monitoring project progress
    • Allowing timely identification of delays
    • Enhancing interdepartmental communication
    • Supporting real-time progress reporting
  • PERT is especially useful when time estimation is uncertain, as it allows for calculating expected durations using optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely time estimates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Critical path method (CPM): Similar to PERT but is used when activity durations are more predictable. It focuses on identifying the longest path of dependent activities (the critical path), but PERT is better when time variability is a concern.

 

Option B. Planning, Programming, Budgeting System (PPBS): This is a budgeting and resource allocation tool, not a scheduling or sequencing tool. It does not use arrow diagrams.

 

Option C. Network analysis: This is a general term for methods like PERT and CPM, but it does not refer to a specific, named technique. In this context, PERT is the precise answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PERT is a project management tool that uses arrow diagrams to represent task sequences and is used for planning, scheduling, and monitoring complex projects.

questions.text: A public health team is investigating an outbreak of convulsions, hallucinations, and peripheral ischemia among villagers in a rural region following consumption of contaminated grains. Laboratory analysis confirms the presence of toxic alkaloids associated with ergotism. Which of the following fungal organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Claviceps purpurea

 

  • Claviceps purpurea is a fungus that infects rye and other cereal grains, producing ergot alkaloids such as ergometrine and ergotamine. 
  • Consumption of contaminated grains leads to ergotism, characterized by:
    • Vasoconstriction → gangrene, ischemia
    • Neurotoxic effects → hallucinations, convulsions
    • GI symptoms
  • Historically known as “St. Anthony’s Fire,” ergotism has been responsible for epidemics in regions consuming poorly stored grains. 
  • The diagnosis is supported by history of exposure and clinical features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus flavus: Produces aflatoxins, which are hepatotoxic and carcinogenic, particularly linked to liver cancer. Not associated with ergotism.

 

Option C. Fusarium species: Produces mycotoxins like fumonisins and trichothecenes, leading to foodborne illnesses, but not ergot alkaloids.

 

Option D. Rhizopus species: Associated with mucormycosis, particularly in immunocompromised patients (e.g., diabetics), not with foodborne toxin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Claviceps purpurea causes ergotism by producing toxic alkaloids in contaminated grains, leading to vasoconstriction and neurotoxic symptoms.

questions.text: During a period of intense exercise, a 23-year-old athlete experiences muscle fatigue due to reduced oxygen availability in skeletal muscle. Despite this, glycolysis continues to generate ATP under anaerobic conditions. The NAD⁺ required to sustain glycolysis is regenerated through a compensatory metabolic reaction. Which of the following enzymes is directly responsible for regenerating NAD⁺ under these anaerobic conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactate dehydrogenase

 

During anaerobic glycolysis, cells are unable to regenerate NAD⁺ through oxidative phosphorylation due to limited oxygen. However, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (G3PDH) in glycolysis requires NAD⁺ to function. The enzyme lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) compensates for this by reducing pyruvate to lactate, while simultaneously oxidizing NADH to NAD⁺, thus sustaining glycolytic flux. This is crucial for ATP generation in hypoxic or anaerobic conditions, such as intense exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: A mitochondrial enzyme involved in the TCA cycle. It does not regenerate NAD⁺ in the cytosol during anaerobic glycolysis.

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in gluconeogenesis, and is not involved in NAD⁺ regeneration during anaerobic glycolysis.

 

Option D. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: A key TCA cycle enzyme that produces NADH from isocitrate. It functions under aerobic conditions and does not help regenerate NAD⁺ for glycolysis under anaerobic stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anaerobic conditions, lactate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, regenerating NAD⁺ to support continued glycolytic ATP production.

questions.text: Which of the following types of stimuli produces only a local potential, but not an action potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subthreshold  

 

  • A local potential refers to a small change in the membrane potential that does not reach the threshold required to generate an action potential. 
  • Local potentials occur in response to a stimulus but are graded, decremental, and reversible—meaning they can either depolarize or hyperpolarize the membrane, but they do not propagate like an action potential. 
  • This is a stimulus that is too weak to reach the threshold and, therefore, only produces a local potential but not an action potential. 
  • The local depolarization may occur, but it is insufficient to trigger the opening of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels needed for an action potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximal stimulus: This refers to the minimum stimulus strength that produces the greatest response in a nerve or muscle. If it reaches or exceeds threshold, it will generate an action potential.

 

Option B. Supramaximal stimulus: This is a stimulus stronger than the maximal but does not increase the response beyond that produced by a maximal stimulus because all excitable fibers are already recruited.

 

Option C. Threshold stimulus: This is the minimum stimulus strength required to generate an action potential. At this level, voltage-gated Na⁺ channels open, leading to depolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A subthreshold stimulus results in a local potential that does not trigger an action potential. Action potentials follow the "all-or-none" principle, meaning that only stimuli that reach or exceed the threshold can generate an action potential. 
  • Local potentials are graded, decremental, and reversible, while action potentials are non-decremental and propagate along excitable membranes.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman from Hyderabad presents with progressive abdominal distension, right upper quadrant discomfort, and yellowing of her eyes for the past month. She also reports early satiety and fatigue. On examination, she has leukonychia, and shifting dullness. Abdominal wall image of the patient is shown below:

 

 

There is no history of recent medication use or overdose. She does not report confusion or altered sensorium.

Investigations:

  • ALT: 43 U/L 
  • AST: 146 U/L 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liver cirrhosis

 

  • This patient’s presentation—right upper quadrant pain, abdominal swelling, jaundice (scleral icterus), leukonychia, visible abdominal wall veins, and ascites—is highly suggestive of liver cirrhosis resulting from chronic liver injury. 
  • The AST:ALT ratio >2 supports the diagnosis, particularly in the context of alcohol-related liver disease. 
  • Although she has features of decompensation (ascites, jaundice), there is no encephalopathy or significant coagulopathy to suggest acute liver failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute liver failure: Typically involves rapid deterioration, encephalopathy, and coagulopathy, not the chronic features seen here.

 

Option B. Haemochromatosis: A slowly progressive condition of iron overload, usually associated with elevated ferritin and transferrin saturation.

 

Option C. Hepatocellular carcinoma: May occur on a background of cirrhosis, but would require imaging or raised AFP levels; this clinical picture fits cirrhosis more closely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Liver cirrhosis presents with classic signs of chronic liver disease, such as ascites, jaundice, and stigmata like leukonychia and spider naevi. 
  • A high AST:ALT ratio (>2) can point toward alcoholic cirrhosis. Recognizing these features early helps guide management and prevent further decompensation.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man from Jaipur presents to the nephrology clinic with intermittent flank pain and visible blood in his urine for the past 24 hours. He denies trauma or recent strenuous exercise. He also notes mild swelling in his ankles, especially in the evenings. On further questioning, he reports recovering from a sore throat and low-grade fever 2 days ago, which resolved without antibiotics. On examination, he has bilateral pitting pedal edema, but no fever, rash, or signs of systemic illness.

Investigations:

  • Urinalysis: Protein (+), Blood (+), Glucose (–), Leukocytes (–)
  • Renal biopsy: 

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgA nephropathy

 

  • IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease) is the most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide. 
  • It typically presents with gross hematuria shortly after a mucosal infection such as an upper respiratory tract infection—within 24–48 hours, unlike post-streptococcal GN which occurs after 1–3 weeks. 
  • The renal biopsy showing mesangial hypercellularity with IgA deposits confirms the diagnosis. 
  • Proteinuria and hematuria are hallmarks of a nephritic syndrome. Clinical outcomes can range from benign to progressive renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antiglomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease: Also known as Goodpasture’s syndrome, it presents with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, hemoptysis, and linear IgG deposits on biopsy.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN): Presents with mixed nephritic/nephrotic features and is associated with complement dysregulation, not typically with a recent URI.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease (MCD): Common in children presenting with massive proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome, without hematuria. Renal biopsy is usually normal on light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IgA nephropathy is the most common primary glomerulonephritis, often triggered by a recent upper respiratory tract infection, leading to hematuria within 24–48 hours. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by renal biopsy showing mesangial proliferation with IgA deposits. Early onset following infection helps distinguish it from post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man working in an abattoir presents with a painless pustule on his forearm that evolved into a black-centered ulcer with surrounding edema. He recently handled raw animal hides. A smear is taken from the ulcer and sent for laboratory evaluation to identify the causative organism. Which of the following stains is most appropriate to detect the likely pathogen responsible for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichrome methylene blue

 

  • This clinical picture is typical of cutaneous anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, a gram-positive, spore-forming rod found in animals and animal products. 
  • The disease manifests as a painless papule that progresses to a black eschar.
  • The best stain for identifying Bacillus anthracis in clinical samples is Trichrome (or polychrome) methylene blue, which allows visualization of the bacterial capsule—a diagnostic feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbol fuchsin: Used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining to detect acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not suitable for Bacillus anthracis.

 

Option C. Acid-fast stain: Detects mycolic acid-containing organisms (e.g., Mycobacterium, Nocardia), not useful for identifying B. anthracis, which is not acid-fast.

 

Option D. Gram stain: While Bacillus anthracis is gram-positive, Gram stain does not highlight the capsule, which is important for specific identification in anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis is best identified using trichrome (polychrome) methylene blue, which highlights the capsule—critical for early diagnosis in exposed individuals.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is receiving immunosuppressive therapy following a renal transplant. As part of his treatment, he is given a nucleotide derivative that exerts its effect by being converted into an active metabolite. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Azathioprine

 

  • Azathioprine is a nucleotide derivative and immunosuppressive agent commonly used in organ transplant recipients to prevent graft rejection.
  • It is a prodrug that is converted to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) in the body.
  • 6-MP then inhibits de novo purine synthesis, which suppresses lymphocyte proliferation, as lymphocytes rely heavily on this pathway.
  • Its use in renal transplant patients is well-established for long-term immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: A cytidine analog used primarily in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It inhibits DNA polymerase, not purine synthesis, and is not used for transplant immunosuppression.

 

Option C. 5-Fluorouracil: A pyrimidine analog that inhibits thymidylate synthase, used in solid tumors such as colon and breast cancers. It is not used in organ transplant settings.

 

Option D. Mercaptopurine: While it is the active metabolite of azathioprine, it is not typically used directly for immunosuppression post-transplant. It is more commonly used in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and requires careful dose adjustment if combined with allopurinol, due to risk of toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Azathioprine is a purine analog and immunosuppressive drug used in kidney transplant patients. 
  • It is a nucleotide derivative that inhibits purine synthesis by converting to 6-mercaptopurine, thereby suppressing lymphocyte proliferation.

questions.text: A clinical trial is assessing time-to-event outcomes (survival) in patients receiving two different cancer therapies. The data are plotted using Kaplan-Meier survival curves for both groups. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate for comparing the difference in survival between the two groups, while accounting for covariates?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cox proportional hazards model

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is a regression technique used to analyze survival data, particularly when comparing Kaplan-Meier survival curves. It allows for:
    • Comparison of survival between groups
    • Adjustment for covariates (e.g., age, gender, comorbidities)
    • Estimation of hazard ratios to quantify relative risk over time
  • This makes it ideal for analyzing and comparing survival data in clinical research.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bland-Altman analysis: Used to compare agreement between two quantitative measurement methods, not for survival analysis.

 

Option C. Chi-square test: Used for binary outcomes (e.g., dead or alive), but does not account for time-to-event data, making it inappropriate for comparing survival curves.

 

Option D. One-way ANOVA: Used to compare means across multiple groups, assuming normally distributed continuous data, not applicable for survival/time-to-event data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used to compare Kaplan-Meier survival curves, especially when adjusting for covariates in time-to-event analysis.

choices.text: They require antigen presentation via MHC class II molecules
They are a subtype of T-helper (CD4+) cells
They are primarily located in gastrointestinal tract epithelium
They mediate their functions indirectly via B-cell activation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding γδ-T cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They are primarily located in gastrointestinal tract epithelium

 

  • γδ-T cells are a unique subset of T lymphocytes that express a gamma-delta T-cell receptor (TCR) instead of the conventional alpha-beta TCR.
  • They are most abundant in epithelial tissues, particularly the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and skin.
  • These cells are part of the innate-like immune response, responding rapidly to antigenic challenges.
  • Unlike αβ T cells, γδ-T cells do not require MHC-mediated antigen presentation and can recognize a variety of non-peptide antigens.
  • Some subsets have cytotoxic functions, while others secrete cytokines like IFN-γ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They require antigen presentation via MHC class II molecules Incorrect. γδ-T cells do not require classical MHC restriction (neither class I nor class II). They can recognize antigens without MHC presentation.

 

Option B. They are a subtype of T-helper (CD4+) cells: Incorrect. γδ-T cells are not classified as CD4+ helper cells. While they may produce cytokines, they do not follow the CD4/CD8 lineage of conventional αβ T cells.

 

Option D. They mediate their functions indirectly via B-cell activation: Incorrect. γδ-T cells can exert direct cytotoxic effects and release cytokines in response to stress antigens, not primarily via B-cell modulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • γδ-T cells are a distinct subset of T cells predominantly found in epithelial tissues such as the gastrointestinal tract and can respond to antigenic stimuli without MHC restriction.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency are more prone to developing panacinar emphysema predominantly in the lower lobes of the lungs.

 

Reason (R): In α1-antitrypsin deficiency, unchecked protease activity results in widespread alveolar wall destruction due to the absence of antiprotease protection.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

 

Assertion: True In α1-antitrypsin deficiency, the lack of inhibition of neutrophil elastase leads to destruction of entire acini (panacinar emphysema). This form of emphysema has a lower lobe predominance due to higher perfusion (and thus more neutrophils and enzyme activity) at the lung bases.

 

Reason: True and correctly explains the assertion
α1-antitrypsin is a serine protease inhibitor (SERPIN) that protects alveolar tissue from enzymatic degradation. Its deficiency permits unopposed protease activity, especially elastase, which degrades elastin in the alveolar walls.

 

Thus, the increased susceptibility to panacinar emphysema in the lower lobes is directly explained by the lack of A1AT-mediated inhibition of proteases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Panacinar emphysema, typically affecting the lower lobes, is associated with α1-antitrypsin deficiency due to unopposed protease activity leading to diffuse alveolar destruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male veterinarian presents with pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO), malaise, and weight loss over several weeks. Blood cultures, incubated in specialized laboratory media, grow gram-negative short bacilli that are oxidase positive. Based on his occupational exposure, a zoonotic infection is suspected. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brucella spp

 

  • Brucella spp are gram-negative coccobacilli that grow on enriched media (like Castaneda or blood culture media), often requiring prolonged incubation.
  • They are oxidase positive and cause brucellosis, a zoonotic infection frequently seen in veterinarians, farmers, and slaughterhouse workers.
  • Brucellosis typically presents with pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO), night sweats, arthralgia, and weight loss.
  • It is transmitted via direct contact with infected animals or ingestion of unpasteurized dairy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Francisella spp: Francisella tularensis is a fastidious, oxidase-negative, gram-negative coccobacillus. It causes tularemia and requires cysteine-enriched media. Not typically associated with positive blood cultures.

 

Option C. Pasteurella spp: These are oxidase positive but commonly cause soft tissue infections following animal bites or scratches, not PUO. Blood culture positivity is rare.

 

Option D. Coxiella burnetii: Causative agent of Q fever, presents with PUO, but it is an obligate intracellular organism, and does not grow in standard blood culture media. Diagnosis is serological, not culture-based.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brucella spp are oxidase-positive, gram-negative coccobacilli that cause brucellosis, a zoonotic infection associated with occupational exposure in veterinarians, and are identified in blood cultures using enriched media.
